{{Italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{about|the official record of debates in the New Zealand Parliament, commonly called "Hansard"|the parliamentary records of other Commonwealth countries|Hansard}} '''''Parliamentary Debates (Hansard)''''' is the official name of the transcripts of debates in the [[New Zealand Parliament]]. New Zealand was one of the first countries to establish an independent team of ''[[Hansard]]'' reporters,[http://www.history.net.nz/politics/history-of-parliament/reporting-and-broadcasting Parliaments' People, NZHistory site, NZ Ministry for Culture & Heritage] 42 years before [[Parliament of Great Britain|Westminister]]. An official record of debates has been kept continuously since 9 July 1867. Speeches made in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] and the [[New Zealand Legislative Council|Legislative Council]] between 1867 and the commencement of [[Parliament of New Zealand|Parliament]] in 1854 were compiled in 1885 from earlier newspaper reports, and this compilation also forms part of the [[New Zealand]] ''[[Hansard]]'' record. ==History== [[File:Cartoon_about_NZ_Parliamentary_Debates_from_NZ_Observer_12_October_1895.jpg|400px|right|NZ Observer & Free Lance 1895]] For 13 years from the establishment of the [[Parliament of New Zealand|NZ Parliament]] in [[Auckland]] in 1854 newspaper reports were the only record of what Members said in debates in the [[New Zealand Legislative Council|Legislative Council]] and the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House of Representatives]]. The accuracy of these reports often depended on the political leanings of the owners of the newspaper in which they were published, and consistency of reporting was a real problem,[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19310416.2.46? Evening Post, 16 April 1931, page 11] as noted in an article in the ''Wellington Independent'' newspaper in 1860:[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WI18601009.2.11 Wellington Independent, 9 October 1860, page 3]
“''These reports give you little notion of the reality. Some members … whose speeches are dreary beyond belief, and almost unintelligible as delivered in the House, [become] flowing oratory in the columns of the newspaper. While others… are shorn of their fair proportions, and their speeches reduced to mere notes… Members who usually talk to empty benches [appear] as prominent as those who electrify the gallery or are the life of the House.''”
[[MPs|MP]] [[William Fitzherbert (New Zealand politician)|William Fitzherbert]] brought a motion to the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] in 1856 calling for funds to be applied to "''secure accurate and authentic reports of the substance and arguments of the speeches''".[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740189;view=1up;seq=202 ''Parliamentary Debates 1856–1858'', 12 June 1856, page 152] Then in 1862 [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]] ([[MPs|MP]] for Christchurch and owner of ''[[The Press]]'') introduced a motion calling on the Government to take steps to secure the publication of "''full and accurate reports of the debates in this House''".[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740205;view=1up;seq=672 ''Parliamentary Debates 1861–1863'', 25 August 1862, page 606] Despite both motions being unanimously agreed, it was not until 1866 that a Select Committee, chaired by [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|FitzGerald]], was established to “''consider and report as to the best manner in which the debates of the General Assembly can be reported and printed''.”[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740213;view=1up;seq=833 ''Parliamentary Debates 1864–1866'', 5 July 1866, page 761] On 9 July 1867 a team of five reporters (AJ Dallas, George McIntyre, James Kinsella, ET Gillon, and William Mitchell who later drowned[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS18980624.2.54 Auckland Star, 24 June 1898, page 5]),[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/DSC18671014.2.26? Daily Southern Cross 14 October 1867, page 4][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH18920712.2.30 New Zealand Herald, 12 July 1892, page 5][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH18840325.2.18 New Zealand Herald, 25 March 1884, page 5] led by Chief Reporter [[C.C.N. Barron]], produced the first official report of debates of the [[Parliament of New Zealand]].[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18920711.2.10 [[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]], 11 July 1892, page 2][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18880709.2.8 [[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]], 9 July 1888, page 2] One notable ''Hansard'' Reporter from the 1870s and 1880s was [[George Fisher (New Zealand politician)|George Fisher]], who was mayor of [[Wellington]] for four terms, member of Parliament for Wellington and Minister of Education and Commissioner of Trade and Customs.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18840403.2.36 Otago Daily Times, 3 April 1884, page 4] Another notable early ''Hansard'' Reporter was Charles Melville Crombie, who later became Chief Commissioner of Taxes.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18940607.2.11 Evening Post, 7 June 1894, page 2] [[File:Cartoon_about_NZ_Parliamentary_Debates_from_NZ_Observer_25_Aug._1894.jpg|400px|right|NZ Observer & Free Lance 1894]] Reporters worked in 15 minute "turns" and had to cover speeches in both debating chambers, regularly working until after midnight to finish the day's reports, taking notes using [[Pitman shorthand]] and then transcribing these by dictation. From the establishment of the ''Hansard'' team speeches were reported as fully as possible, although for many years it was regularly proposed that only summaries of speeches should be published.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18880709.2.8? Evening Post, 9 July 1888, page 2] Reporters had to cope with speakers who had a variety of different accents and speaking pace, and had to learn the names of an increasing number of members, with the [[New Zealand House of Representatives#Number of members|number of members]] in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] alone increasing from 37 in 1854 to 95 by 1882. Competent reporters with [[shorthand]] skills were scarce in New Zealand and men were brought in during parliamentary sessions from Australian parliaments to assist local reporters. In 1884 Maurice FitzGerald, son of [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]], was engaged to compile from newspaper reports speeches made in Parliament between 1854 and 1867.[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18841108.2.12 Evening Post, 8 November 1884, page 2][http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/HBH18841110.2.12.1 Hawke's Bay Herald, 10 November 1884, page 3][http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/THD18841110.2.13 Timaru Herald, 10 November 1884, page 2][http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/HBH18841111.2.10? Hawke's Bay Herald, 11 November 1884, page 3] Maurice Fitzgerald completed this work in 1885.Letter from Maurice FitzGerald to [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|Premier]] [[Robert Stout]] 22 August 1885, Archives NZ reference R24418249[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TAN18860424.2.28 Te Aroha News, 24 April 1886, page 5] He died in 1886 (at 25 years of age) from [[Tuberculosis]][http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18860710.2.13 Evening Post, 10 July 1886, page 2][http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/MEX18860712.2.9 Marlborough Express, 12 July 1886, page 2][http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TH18860713.2.12.1 Taranaki Herald, 13 July 1886, page 2] before all five volumes of his compilation were printed.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740213;view=1up;seq=1127 ''Parliamentary Debates 1864–1866'', Postscript, page 1055][http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18860720.2.12 Evening Post, 20 July 1886, page 2] ==New Zealand ''Hansard'' today== Official transcripts of [[MPs]] speeches in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] have been continuously published since 1867. Today ''Hansard'' is produced by a team of about 17 [[Full-time equivalent|FTE]] Hansard Editors within the [[Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives]]. ''Hansard'' is published on the [[New Zealand Parliament]] website each day the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] sits, and later indexed bound volumes are produced. Speeches are transcribed directly from digital recordings of the debate, with staff present in the [[debating chamber]] to monitor the debate by recording the sequence of speakers and any interjections. Interjections are reported only if the member speaking replies to them or remarks on them during the course of his or her speech. Hansard Editors follow strict rules on what changes they can make to the words [[MPs]] use in the [[debating chamber]]. ''Hansard'' is as close to [[wikt:verbatim|verbatim]] as possible, although Hansard Editors remove repetitions and redundancies and make minor grammatical corrections. [[MPs]] are provided draft copies of their speeches at the same time that the speeches are first published on the Parliament website. [[MPs]] can request correction of inadvertent factual inaccuracies but they are unable to significantly change what they said in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]].[https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/hansard-debates/what-is-hansard/ New Zealand Parliament website, "What is Hansard?", Retrieved 13 September 2016][https://www.parliament.nz/en/get-involved/features-pre-2016/document/00NZPHomeNews270420091/650th-bound-edition-of-hansard-published New Zealand Parliament website, "650th bound edition of Hansard published", Retrieved 13 September 2016] ==Timeline of establishment of ''Hansard'' in New Zealand== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Event or decision relevant to reporting of debates |- |24 May 1854 |The General Assembly sat for the first time, with an upper house, the [[New Zealand Legislative Council|Legislative Council]], consisting of 12 appointed Legislative Counselors, and a [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] consisting of 37[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZSCSG18530312.2.8 Proclamation from Government Gazette of 10 March 1853, New Zealand Spectator and Cook's Strait Guardian, 12 March 1853, page 3] elected Members of the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]]. |- |May/June 1854 |A "reporting club" of [[MPs]] was formed, consisting of [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]], [[Henry Sewell]], [[Edward Gibbon Wakefield]], [[Jerningham Wakefield|Edward Jerningham Wakefield]], [[James Macandrew]], [[Hugh Carleton]] and [[William Cutten]]. Because of the lack of [[news media|press]] reporters with [[shorthand]] skills this group undertook to take notes of speeches in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]], which would then be provided to each member who had spoken for checking, before being provided to newspapers for publication.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740171;view=1up;seq=230 ''Parliamentary Debates 1854–1855'', 7 July 1854, page 184][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/DSC18540919.2.9 The Southern Cross, 19 September 1854, page 3] The collegiality of members of the reporting club was short-lived: by early July [[Henry Sewell]] complained that [[Edward Gibbon Wakefield]] "''does not scruple here and there to doctor and color what has been really said, not absolutely falsifying, and yet giving slight touches which wholly alter the real character... his speeches are embellished throughout with cheers, as if the House sympathized heartily''".{{cite book|ref = JHS |last = Sewell|first = Henry|title = The Journal of Henry Sewell 1853–7 : Volume 2|year = 1980|publisher = Whitcoulls Publishers|location = Christchurch|isbn = 0723306230|authorlink = Henry Sewell|editor = W. David McIntyre|page = 54}} |- |12 June 1856 |[[MPs]] agreed a motion moved by [[William Fitzherbert (New Zealand politician)|William Fitzherbert]] calling for funds to be applied to "''secure accurate and authentic reports of the substance and arguments of the speeches made by honorable members of the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]]''" |- |25 August 1862 |[[MPs]] agreed a motion moved by [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]] calling on the Government to take steps to secure the publication of "''full and accurate reports of the debates in this [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]]''" |- |2 December 1863 |[[MPs]] reaffirm the motion moved by [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]] calling on the Government to take steps to secure the publication of "''full and accurate reports of the debates in this [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]]''"[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740205;view=1up;seq=1039''Parliamentary Debates 1861–1863'', 2 December 1863, page 973] |- |8 & 14 August 1865 |[[MPs]] agreed a motion moved by [[Frederick Weld]]: "''That a Select Committee be appointed to superintend the revision of the reports of debates''"[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740213;view=1up;seq=329 ''Parliamentary Debates 1864–1866'', 8 August 1865, page 257] A similar motion moved by [[James Crowe Richmond]] was passed in the [[New Zealand Legislative Council|Legislative Council]][https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740213;view=1up;seq=370 ''Parliamentary Debates 1864–1866'', 14 August 1865, page 298] |- |5 & 17 July 1866 |[[MPs]] agreed a motion moved by [[Edward Stafford (politician)|Edward Stafford]] "''That a Select Committee be appointed to consider and report as to the best manner in which the debates of the General Assembly can be reported and printed.''" This Committee reported to the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] that the Government should eventually "''engage a staff of competent reporters''" but until that could be done the [[Wellington]] newspapers should be paid to "''furnish full and accurate reports daily of the proceedings in both Houses.''"[https://www.atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&cl=search&d=AJHR1866-I.2.1.7.3&srpos=69&e=-------100--1---bySH---0-AJHR%5f1866%5fI%5fAZz-G- ''Appendix to the Journals of the House of Representatives'', 1866 Session I, F-03, 13 July 1866][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/DSC18660730.2.25 Daily Southern Cross, 30 July 1866, page 4][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP18660713.2.7 Evening Post, 13 July 1866, page 2] However the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] refused to agree a resolution moved by Committee Chairman [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]] to enter into a contract with local newspaper proprietors, as had been proposed by the report.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740213;view=1up;seq=853 ''Parliamentary Debates 1864–1866'', 17 July 1866, page 781][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/CHP18660721.2.13? ''[[The Press]]'', 21 July 1866, page 2][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WI18660719.2.17.2 Wellington Independent, 19 July 1866, page 6] |- |26 July 1866 |[[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]] drew the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House's]] attention to the fact that newspapers were deliberately omitting to report the speeches, or even the name, of a certain member. A note in ''Hansard'' indicates that FitzGerald was referring to the Wellington newspapers purposely omitting any mention of [[Dillon Bell|Francis Dillon Bell]].[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740213;view=1up;seq=889 ''Parliamentary Debates 1864–1866'', 26 July 1866, page 817] |- |28 September 1866 |Thomas MacKenzie, proprietor of the ''Wellington Independent'' newspaper was summoned to appear before the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] for a "''breach of [[Parliamentary Privilege|Privilege]]''" by publishing a report of parliamentary debates that indicated that [[Arthur John Burns]] (Member for [[Caversham (New Zealand electorate)|Caversham]]) had acted [[Malice (law)|maliciously]] by raising a certain matter in [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]].[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH18661008.2.27? New Zealand Herald, 8 October 1866, page 5][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WI18661016.2.16 Wellington Independent, 16 October 1866, page 6][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WI18661002.2.13 Wellington Independent, 2 October 1866, page 5] |- |9 July 1867 |[[C.C.N. Barron|Clarke Charles Netterville Barron]] is appointed as Chief Reporter and tasked with establishing a team of reporters to record debates in both Houses of Parliament. [https://www.atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&cl=search&d=AJHR1868-I.2.1.5.14&srpos=65&e=-------100--1---bySH---0-AJHR%5f1868%5fI%5fAZz-F- ''Appendix to the Journals of the House of Representatives'', 1868 Session I, D-13, 1 July 1868] |- |10 July 1867 |[[Colonial Secretary (New Zealand)|Colonial Secretary]] [[Edward Stafford (politician)|Edward Stafford]] advised the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] that the Government had established "''a reporting staff of four persons, and a head of the staff, who will take down and report the proceedings of both Houses, which will be printed''". A Select Committee was appointed to "''have entire control over the reporting''"... this was an "''experiment''"; the Select "''Committee was to ascertain whether the present arrangements could be improved.''"[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740221;view=1up;seq=63 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 1.1'', 10 July 1867, pages 16–22] The ''Wellington Independent'' derided the government's decision to establish a team of ''Hansard'' reporters, rather than enter into a contract with local newspapers to report on debates.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WI18670611.2.10 Wellington Independent, 11 June 1867, page 3][https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/WI18670615.2.30 Wellington Independent, 15 June 1867, page 7] |- |16 July 1867 |The Select Committee on Reporting Debates adopted rules that allowed Members "''the opportunity of revising reports, on the strict understanding that the alterations are to be confined to making the reports more in accordance with the remarks actually uttered in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]]. The head reporter to be the judge of the alterations made, and to refuse to pass those which he considers are departures from a correct report of what the speaker said.''"[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740221;view=1up;seq=102 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 1.1'', 16 July 1867, page 56] |- |6 August 1868 |After lengthy debate, the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] refused to agree a resolution moved by [[Charles Heaphy]] that "''having in view the burdensome taxation of the country... the present system of reporting the debates, and the expense thereof, should cease with the termination of existing contracts.''"[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740239;view=1up;seq=337 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 2'', 6 August 1868, page 311] |- |1 September 1869 |A Reporting Debates Committee appointed by the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] on 4 June 1869 "''for the purpose of regulating the proceedings of the reporters, and endeavouring to provide for the better compilation of the reports''"[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740270;view=1up;seq=56 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 5'', 4 June 1869, page 32] reaffirmed the rule established by the 1867 Select Committee on Reporting Debates that if Members seek to make material alterations in the reports of their speeches the '''Chief Reporter should have the power to refuse to pass such corrections to the Printer''".[https://www.atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&d=AJHR1869-I.2.2.6.9&srpos=65&e=-------10--1------0-- ''Appendix to the Journals of the House of Representatives'', 1869 Session I, F-08, 30 August 1869] |- |14 July 1870 |The Reporting Debates Committee considered, but did not agree to, a proposal by [[John Davies Ormond]] (Member for [[Clive (New Zealand electorate)|Clive]]) that ''"Hansard staff should be required to prepare summaries of the debates in the House for transmission by telegraph to the various newspapers of the colony"''.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/HBT18700725.2.11? Hawke's Bay Times, 25 July 1870, page 4] |- |14 November 1871 |[[MPs]] agreed a motion moved by [[William Henry Harrison (New Zealand politician)|William Harrison]]: "''That, with the view to improving the character of Hansard, a permanent staff of efficient reporters should be engaged for that service,''" (at that time most reporters were employed on a sessional basis) "''and that it should be a primary duty of the Chief Reporter to take his share in the task of reporting.''" (The Chief Reporter was currently mostly doing administration and checking reports, rather than reporting.)[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740320;view=1up;seq=1123 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 11'', 14 November 1871, pages 1077–1079] |- |24 September & 25 October 1872 |[[MPs]] noted a marked improvement in ''[[Hansard]]'' due to the appointment of permanent reporters[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740346;view=1up;seq=345''Parliamentary Debates Volume 13'', 24 September 1872, pages 304–305][https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740346;view=1up;seq=986 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 13'', 25 October 1872, page 946] |- |28 July 1875 |After lengthy debate, the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] refused to agree a proposal from the Reporting Debates Committee that "''Hansard reporters be directed to report "short" those debates which are not of general public interest.''" This proposal would have seen many speeches reported in a précis format, with only "''matters of political importance... reported as nearly as possible in extenso''".[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019787149;view=1up;seq=101 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 17'', 28 July 1875, pages 73 – 76] |- |8 August 1879 |[[MPs]] again rejected a proposal brought by the Reporting Debates and Printing Committee that would have allowed the Chief Reporter "''the exercise of a discretionary power as to reporting matters arising incidentally in the House, and not set down as business of the day'' [because] ''with the limited staff at his disposal, it was impossible... to report everything that took place in the House''".[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019787271;view=1up;seq=528 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 31'', 8 August 1879, page 505] |- |3 December 1879 |[[MPs]] again rejected a proposal brought by the Reporting Debates committees of both houses "''that the debates published in Hansard shall be condensed next session''".[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019787313;view=1up;seq=141 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 34'', 3 December 1879, page 639] |- |7 July 1880 |[[MPs]] agreed a motion "''that it be an instruction to the Printing and Debates Committee to inquire into and report to this House in what manner retrenchment can best be effected in the cost of the publication of Hansard.''"[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019787321;view=1up;seq=84''Parliamentary Debates Volume 36'', 7 July 1880, page 54] |- |15 June 1882 |[[MPs]] rejected a motion "''that members shall defray the cost of printing their own speeches in Hansard; and that such cost shall be deducted from the honorarium, if any, to which they may be entitled''". (If it had been passed this motion would have allowed members to choose whether or not their speeches were reported in ''Hansard''.)''".[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019787362;view=1up;seq=507 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 41'', 15 June 1882, page 471] |- |7 November 1884 |[[William Steward (New Zealand politician)|William Steward]] advised the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] that the Reporting Debates and Printing Committee had sanctioned the ordering of four 'Caligraph' typewriters as a trial ''"with a view to adding to the facilities of the reporting staff"''.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019787453;view=1up;seq=500 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 50'', 8 November 1884, page 470] |- |8 November 1884 |[[Prime Minister of New Zealand|Premier]] [[Robert Stout]] advised the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] that Maurice FitzGerald, son of [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]], would be engaged to compile from newspaper reports speeches made in Parliament between 1854 and 1867.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019787453;view=1up;seq=526 ''Parliamentary Debates Volume 50'', 8 November 1884, page 496] This work was completed the following year but the last of the five volume compilation was not printed until 1887. |} ==Volumes== ''Hansard'' has been digitized by [[Google Books#Google Books Library Project|Google]] in partnership with the [[University of California]] ([[University of California Libraries#Santa Cruz|Santa Cruz et al. libraries]]), from the first sitting of the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House]] in May 1854 up to July 1987. These digital volumes are hosted by [[HathiTrust]] and are available via the links in the first column of the table below. The entire collection up to July 1987 is searchable using the [[HathiTrust]] [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/mb?a=listis&c=71329709 website]. The last column of the table below has links to other digital volumes created in partnership with university libraries if these are publicly available via [[HathiTrust]]. ''Hansard'' from 16 September 1987 to 17 December 2002 created from word processing files (i.e. not the official printed volumes) is available via the links in the first column of the table below and the 123 volumes in this period can be downloaded [https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B1Iwfzv-Mt3CRGZkMWNfeXoybmc?usp=sharing here] (this is useful for searching across the collection). ''Hansard'' from 11 February 2003 onwards is available from the [[Parliament of New Zealand|NZ Parliament]] [https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/hansard-debates/ website]. The period 11 February 2003 to 9 June 2016 is also available via the links in the first column of the table below and the 109 volumes in this period can be downloaded in 1885 from earlier newspaper reports.[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106019740171;view=1up;seq=9 Preface to ''Parliamentary Debates 1854–1855''] 2 In 1867 the first official [[New Zealand]] ''[[Hansard]]'' was compiled by reporters employed on a sessional basis. 3 Volume 1.2 includes an appendix of financial data for various years. 4 Volume 146 includes a 61-page appendix: Proceedings of the meetings of both Houses (held 7 June 1909) to discuss the question of representation of NZ at the Imperial Naval Conference. 7 Volume 316 is the first volume to use the title Parliamentary Debates ''(Hansard)''. 8 This digitised volume 326 is missing pages 1 to 128 (20 to 28 June 1961). 9 Volume digitized in partnership with the [[University of Chicago]]. 10 Volume digitized in partnership with [[Harvard University]]. 11 Volume digitized in partnership with the [[University of California]] ([[University of California Libraries#Los Angeles (13 major [[Feminism]] | position = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]]{{cite book|author=Dr Marc Guinjoan|title=Parties, Elections and Electoral Contests: Competition and Contamination Effects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7bSlBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA68|year=2014|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4724-3910-9|page=68}}{{cite book|editor=Tom Lansford|title=Political Handbook of the World 2015|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yNGfBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT1061|year=2015|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4833-7155-9|page=1061}} | predecessor = | successor = | international = | membership = | membership_year = | colours = Orange | colorcode = {{Canadian party colour|QC|QS}} | blank1_title = Policies | blank1 = | seats1_title = Seats in the [[National Assembly of Quebec|National Assembly]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|10|125|hex={{Canadian party colour|QC|QS}}}} | website = {{URL|quebecsolidaire.net/}} | country = Canada | state = Quebec | footnotes = }} '''Québec solidaire''' ('''QS'''; {{IPA-fr|ke.bɛk sɔ.li.daɛ̯ʁ|local}}) is a [[social democracy|social-democratic]]{{cite book|author1=Pascale Dufour|author2=Christophe Traisnel|chapter=Nationalism and Protest: the Sovereignty Movement in Quebec|editor=Miriam Smith|title=Group Politics and Social Movements in Canada: Second Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iG4rAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA262|year= 2014|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-4426-0695-1|page=262}}{{cite book|author=Peter Graefe|chapter=Quebec Nationalism and Quebec Politics|editor1=Bryan M. Evans|editor2=Charles W. Smith|title=Transforming Provincial Politics: The Political Economy of Canada's Provinces and Territories in the Neoliberal Era|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EbdtBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA155|year=2015|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-4426-1179-5|page=155}} and [[Quebec sovereignty movement|sovereigntist]]{{cite book|editor=David Mutimer|title=Canadian Annual Review of Politics and Public Affairs 2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OTuWAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA197|year=2014|publisher=University of Toronto Press, Scholarly Publishing Division|isbn=978-1-4426-1724-7|page=197}} [[List of political parties in Quebec|political party in Quebec]], Canada.{{r|official_historique}} The party and media outlets in Canada usually use the name "Québec solidaire" in both French and English, but the party's name is sometimes translated as "Solidarity Quebec" or "Quebec Solidarity" in foreign English-language media.{{r|wsws|watchingamerica|laborstandard}} ==History== ===Foundation=== Québec solidaire was founded on February 4, 2006 in [[Montreal]] by the merger of the left-wing party [[Union des forces progressistes (Canada)|Union des forces progressistes]] (UFP) and the [[alter-globalization]] political movement [[Option Citoyenne]], led by [[Françoise David]].{{r|official_historique}} It was formed around a number of activists and politicians who had written ''[[Pour un Québec solidaire]]'', a left-wing response to ''[[Pour un Québec lucide]]''. ''Pour un Québec lucide'' presented a distinctly neoliberal analysis of and set of solutions to Quebec's problems, particularly criticizing the [[Quebec sovereignty movement|sovereignty movement]] as distracting from Quebec's real issues and the Quebec social model as inefficient and out-of-date. ''Pour un Québec solidaire'' presented an alternate analysis, and later its writers formed the party Quebec solidaire, taking its name from the manifesto.{{r|thetyee}} ===Merger with ''Option nationale''=== On December 2, 2017, party members approved a merger with the centre-left sovereignist [[Option nationale]] party.{{r|ctv_1.3704508}} ON members approved the merger, which gave them "collective" status within Québec solidaire, on December 10.{{r|ctv_1.3715528}} Jean-François Lisée charged Manon Massé with reneging in unsuccessful deliberations for a putative electoral alliance between the Parti Québécois and Québec Solidaire in 2017.https://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/quebec-election-lisee-defends-attack-on-qs ===Election results=== Québec solidaire's first political venture was to field a candidate, [[Manon Massé]], in an April 10, 2006, by-election in [[Sainte-Marie–Saint-Jacques]]. She received 22% of the vote. On August 14, 2006, there were two by-elections ([[Pointe-aux-Trembles (electoral district)|Pointe-aux-Trembles]] and [[Taillon]]) in which QS received 8% and 7% of the vote. Québec solidaire contested the [[Quebec general election, 2007|2007 Quebec election]]. It won 3.65% of the popular vote and received 144,418 votes, 0.21% behind the Green Party of Quebec. They were also endorsed by the Montreal Central Council of the [[Confédération des syndicats nationaux]] which represents 125,000 members in Quebec. According to an analysis on ''Canadian Dimension,'' this is the first time a trade union in Quebec has endorsed a party more left-wing than the [[Parti Québécois]].{{r|fidler}} On December 8, 2008, the first Quebec Solidaire candidate was elected in the [[Quebec general election, 2008|provincial election]]. [[Amir Khadir]] was elected in the Montreal riding of [[Mercier (provincial electoral district)|Mercier]].{{r|cbc_20081208}} He won his seat for the second term on 2012 election along with another QS candidate Françoise David in Montreal riding of [[Gouin (provincial electoral district)|Gouin]]. [[Manon Massé]] was elected in [[Sainte-Marie–Saint-Jacques]] in the [[Quebec general election, 2014|2014 election]] to become the party's third MNA, joining David and Khadir who were both re-elected. In the [[Quebec general election, 2018|2018 election]] the party gained 7 more seats from former [[Quebec Liberal Party|Liberal]] and Parti Québécois (while also tying the latter in terms of total seats won) ridings after [[Coalition Avenir Québec]], an Autonomous party won the majority of seats. {|class="wikitable" |- !Election !# of candidates !# of seats won !Votes !Change +/- !% of popular vote !Position |- |- ![[Quebec general election, 2007|2007]] |align="center"|123 |{{Composition bar|0|125|hex={{Canadian party colour|QC|QS}}}} |align="center"|144,418 |align="center"|{{steady}} 0 |align="center"|3.64% |{{eliminated|Extra-parliamentary}} |- ![[Quebec general election, 2008|2008]] |align="center"|122 |{{Composition bar|1|125|hex={{Canadian party colour|QC|QS}}}} |align="center"|122,618 |align="center"|{{increase}} 1 |align="center"|3.78% |{{no2|No status}} |- ![[Quebec general election, 2012|2012]] |align="center"|124 |{{Composition bar|2|125|hex={{Canadian party colour|QC|QS}}}} |align="center"|263,111 |align="center"|{{increase}} 1 |align="center"|6.03% |{{no2|No status}} |- ![[Quebec general election, 2014|2014]] |align="center"|124 |{{Composition bar|3|125|hex={{Canadian party colour|QC|QS}}}} |align="center"|323,367 |align="center"|{{increase}} 1 |align="center"|7.63% |{{no2|No status}} |- ![[Quebec general election, 2018|2018]] |align="center"|125 |{{Composition bar|10|125|hex={{Canadian party colour|QC|QS}}}} |align="center"|648,406 |align="center"|{{increase}} 7 |align="center"|16.08% |{{no2|3rd opposition group}} |} ==Current and former Members of the National Assembly== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc;" || '''MNA''' || '''District''' || '''Region''' || '''Years of Service

Labor activist |} ==Ideology== The aim of QS's foundation was to unify the sovereigntist left of the political spectrum in [[Quebec]] by merging the [[Union des forces progressistes (Canada)|Union des forces progressistes]] (UFP) party with the [[Option citoyenne]] social movement.{{cite book|author=Francesca Bargiela-Chiappini|title=The Handbook of Business Discourse|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wOTcr9mrtEUC&pg=PA58|year=2009|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=978-0-7486-2801-8|page=58}}{{cite book|author1=Daniel Robichaud|author2=Francois Cooren|title=Organization and Organizing: Materiality, Agency and Discourse|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vc_77LS14E0C&pg=PA179|date=May 2, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-20733-4|page=179}} In addition to advocating the independence of Quebec from Canada, the party's platform identifies with the concepts of environmentalism, [[feminism]], [[social justice]], [[proportional representation]] and [[participatory democracy]], [[pacifism]], [[aboriginal rights]], and [[alter-globalism]].{{r|official_quisommesnous}} The party favours [[aboriginal rights]], immigration, and [[human dignity]], and opposes discrimination including racism, sexism and [[homophobia]].{{r|official_quisommesnous}} QS describes itself as a [[Quebec sovereignty movement|sovereigntist]], [[Green politics|green]], [[alter-globalization]]ist, and [[Feminism|feminist]] party.{{cite book|author1=Linda Trimble|author2=Jane Arscott|author3=Manon Tremblay|title=Stalled: The Representation of Women in Canadian Governments|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rsvBqIXfJbYC&pg=PA208|date=May 31, 2013|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-2522-1|page=208}} It is the left-most of the four parties presently represented in the National Assembly. At the party's founding, the congress unanimously adopted a document called the ''Déclaration de principes'' (declaration of principles) which laid out the principles and values that led the two organizations to merge. The declaration of principles does not specifically endorse [[social democracy]], socialism or [[communism]], although it includes certain activists and tendencies that do.{{r|pcq|lagauche_manif|riposte}} The document declared:{{r|official_quisommesnous}} * ''"Nous sommes écologistes"'' ("We are [[environmentalism|environmentalists]]") * ''"Nous sommes de gauche"'' ("We are on the [[Left-wing politics|Left]]") * ''"Nous sommes démocrates"'' ("We are democrats") * ''"Nous sommes féministes"'' ("We are [[feminism|feminists]]") * ''"Nous sommes altermondialistes"'' ("We are [[alter-globalists]]") * ''"Nous sommes d'un Québec pluriel"'' ("We are from a plural Quebec") * ''"Nous sommes d'un Québec souverain et solidaire"'' ("We are from a sovereign and united [''literally'': solidarity-showing] Quebec") * ''"Un autre parti, pour un autre Québec!"'' ("Another party, for another Quebec!") ==Structure== As with its predecessors, Québec solidaire has no "party leader". Instead, the party practices [[collective leadership]]. The party's statutes call for it to be represented by a male and female co-spokesperson, one of whom serves in the dual role of party president. If one of the spokespeople is a member of the National Assembly, the other spokesperson remains outside of the legislature and holds the party presidency.{{cite web|last=Simard |first=Mathieu |url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/Amir+Khadir+steps+down+Qu%C3%A9bec+solidaire+spokesperson/7496353/story.html |title=Khadir steps down as Québec solidaire co-leader |publisher=[[The Canadian Press]] |date=November 4, 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-25}} They are sometimes referred to in the media as the ''de facto'' co-leaders of the party.{{r|ledevoir}} The duties generally entrusted to the leader in most other Canadian federal and provincial parties are instead divided among the president, secretary general and male and female spokespeople. The party leadership is assumed by the National Coordinating Committee, composed of 16 persons elected by the founding congress. A person from the team of volunteers will always have a seat. However, as Quebec's election laws requires the appointment of a leader, the party's secretary general, currently Gaétan Châteauneuf,{{r|dgeq}} is the ''[[de jure]]'' party leader recognized by the [[Chief Electoral Officer of Quebec]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-party-leaders-back-on-election-campaign-trail-after-visiting/|title= Quebec party leaders back on election campaign trail after visiting tornado victims|publisher=[[The Canadian Press]]|date=September 23, 2018|accessdate=October 5, 2018}} [[Françoise David]] and [[Amir Khadir]] were the two spokespersons at the party's founding. After the 2012 election where Françoise David won a seat for the first time and Amir Khadir was re-elected, Khadir stepped down as co-spokesperson so a new one could be chosen from outside the legislature. André Frappier served as interim co-spokesperson{{cite web|last=Simard |first=Mathieu |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/story/2012/12/02/montreal-frappier-solidaire.html |title=Québec Solidaire elects interim co-spokesman |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=December 2, 2012 |accessdate=2012-12-02}} until [[Andrés Fontecilla]] was chosen on May 5, 2013 to permanently fill the role.{{cite web |url=http://www.lapresse.ca/actualites/politique-quebecoise/201305/05/01-4647742-quebec-solidaire-choisit-andres-fontecilla-comme-porte-parole.php |title=Québec solidaire choisit Andrés Fontecilla comme porte-parole |publisher=[[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]] |date=May 5, 2013 |accessdate=May 5, 2013}} [[Gabriel Nadeau-Dubois]] and [[Manon Massé]] became the current co-spokespersons of the party on May 21, 2017. [[Alexa Conradi]] was president from the foundation of the party until June 2009 after which Françoise David was named president-spokeswoman.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} The national spokespersons of Québec solidaire have greater visibility than the secretary general and are best known. David has been named Personality of the Year by ''[[Le Point]]'' and Khadir is known for becoming the first elected member of the party, winning the provincial riding of [[Mercier (provincial electoral district)|Mercier]] in 2008. The basic unit of the party is the local association. There is a local association for each of the 125 ridings in Quebec. These local associations are grouped into 19 regional associations, whose primary mandate to support the establishment of local associations.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} In March 2007, Québec solidaire has 61 local associations organized. Students and staff at institutions of higher education are grouped in campus associations that also participate in the democratic life of the party.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} Two national commissions are also part of the structure of Québec solidaire: the Political Committee and the National Commission for Women. The first is composed of 14 thematic committees and is responsible for proposing a program to members. It was responsible for drafting the electoral platform of the party in general elections of 2007. The National Commission for Women is composed of delegates from each region and is responsible for ensuring that feminism is a value which transverses the party.{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} Québec solidaire also includes a number of collectives, made up of members in good standing who may, in compliance with requirements, promote their respective political views within Québec solidaire. Unlike the UFP, these groups do not have formal representation in the Congress, the National Council or other bodies of the party.{{r|official_statuts}} Current collectives include: * ''[[Socialist Alternative (Quebec)|Alternative socialiste]]'', the Quebec section of the [[Committee for a Workers' International]].{{r|alternativesocialiste}} * ''Décroissance conviviale'', a collective which promotes [[degrowth]]. * ''[[Gauche Socialiste]]'', the Quebec section of the [[reunified Fourth International]].{{r|lagauche}} * ''Laïcité'', a collective which promotes the [[separation of church and state]]. * ''Mass critique'', an [[Anti-capitalism|anti-capitalist]] collective. * ''Socialisme Internationale'', the Quebec membership of the [[International Socialists (Canada)|International Socialists]].{{r|socialiste}} * ''Tendance Marxiste Internationale'', the Quebec section of the [[International Marxist Tendency]].{{r|riposte_200909}} * ''[[Option nationale]]'', formerly active as a separate electoral party from 2011 to 2017. The ''[[Communist Party of Quebec|Parti Communiste du Québec – Parti Communiste du Canada]]'' (PCQ-PCC), left QS following its merger with Option nationale in 2017.https://particommunisteduquebec.ca/sur-quebec-solidaire/ ==Leaders== ===Secretary general=== *Danielle Mayor (February 2006 – June 2006) *Régent Séguin (June 2006 – July 2010) *Bernard Larivière (July 2010 – February 2011) *Thérèse Hurteau (February 2011 – March 2011) *Régent Séguin (March 2011 – May 2013) *Pierre-Paul St-Onge (May 2013 – June 2016) *Gaétan Châteauneuf (June 2016 – present){{cite web|url=https://www.ledevoir.com/politique/quebec/493999/quebec-solidaire|title=Les co-porte-parole, un léger avantage pour Québec solidaire|publisher=[[Le Devoir]]|last1=Bélair-Cirino|first1=Marco|last2=Noël|first2=Dave|date=March 15, 2017|accessdate=October 5, 2018}} ===Female co-spokesperson=== *[[Françoise David]] (February 4, 2006 – May 21, 2017) *[[Manon Massé]] (May 21, 2017 – present) ===Male co-spokesperson=== *[[Amir Khadir]] (February 4, 2006 – December 2, 2012) *André Frappier (interim) (December 2, 2012 – May 5, 2013) *[[Andrés Fontecilla]] (May 5, 2013 – May 21, 2017) *[[Gabriel Nadeau-Dubois]] (May 21, 2017 – present) ==See also== * [[Parti de la démocratie socialiste]] * [[Politics of Quebec]] * [[National Assembly of Quebec]] * [[Quebec political parties|Political parties in Quebec]] ==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= {{cite web |title = Alternative Socialiste. The '''Reichsabgabe''' was a [[tax]] on the postal traffic, levied in the [[German Empire]] during the [[World War I|First World War]]. It was introduced to finance the war expenses. The tax was announced in the ‘Tariff Law’ (''Gebührengesetz'') of 21 June 1916 and became effective with the new postal rates of 1 August 1916.
In practice the Reichsabgabe meant a raising of the postal rates, the revenues of which streamed into the treasury of the State instead of the treasury of the ''Deutsche [[Reichspost]]'', the German postal service. The increase of the postal rates was confined to domestic letters and [[postcard]]s; international mail and [[printed matter]]s were excepted.
On 1 October 1918 the Reichsabgabe was raised. Now the printed matter rate was not excepted.
The effects of the Reichsabgabe are illustrated in the following table:
{| class="wikitable" border="1" |+ ! '''Postal item''' || '''From 1906-07-01''' || '''From 1916-08-01''' || '''From 1918-10-01''' |- | local letter || 5 Pfennig || 7½ Pfennig || 10 Pfennig |- | local postcard || 5 Pfennig || 7½ Pfennig || 7½ Pfennig |- | inland letter up to 20 g. || 10 Pfennig || 15 Pfennig || 15 Pfennig |- | inland postcard || 5 Pfennig || 7½ Pfennig || 10 Pfennig |- | inland printed matter up to 50 g. || 3 Pfennig || 3 Pfennig || 5 Pfennig |- | international letter up to 20 g. || 20 Pfennig || 20 Pfennig || 20 Pfennig |- | international postcard || 10 Pfennig || 10 Pfennig || 10 Pfennig |}
Apart from Germany the Reichsabgabe also applied to the parts of [[Poland]] and the [[Russian Empire]] occupied by Germany and to the occupied Grand Duchy of [[Luxembourg]], but not to the occupied part of [[Belgium]].
The Reichsabgabe was ended on 1 October 1919 in conformance to a law of 8 September 1919. However, the raisings of the postal rates were not reversed.
==References== *Jeroen van de Weide and Ton Welvaart, ‘Eerste inflatieperiode in het Generaalgouvernement Warschau en bezet Rusland; enkele woorden over de Duitse inflatie voor Polenfilatelisten’, in: ''Inflatieperioden en geldhervormingen in Oost Europa'', Filatelistische Contactgroep Oost Europa, 2007 (in Dutch). *Jeroen van de Weide and Ton Welvaart, ‘Erste Inflationsperiode im Generalgouvernement Warschau und im besetzten Russland; einige Worte über die Deutsche Inflation für Polenphilatelisten’, in: ''Inflationsperioden und Währungsreformen in Ost-Europa'', Filatelistische Contactgroep Oost Europa, 2007 (the same article in German). *''Michel Postgebühren-Handbuch Deutschland'', Schwaneberger Verlag, München, 2001 and 2004 (in German).
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reichsabgabe}} [[Category:History of taxation]] [[Category:German Empire in World War I]] [[Category:Postal history]] [[Category:Abolished taxes]]
