revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Restore Our Future |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = |type = |status = Active |purpose = Elect [[Mitt Romney]] as President |headquarters = |location = |favorite color = Blue |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.restoreourfuture.com/ Restore Our Future] }}
'''Restore Our Future''' is a [[political action committee]] (PAC) created to support [[Mitt Romney]] in the [[2012 U.S. Presidential election]]. A so-called [[Super PAC]], Restore Our Future is permitted to raise and spend unlimited amounts of corporate, union, and individual [[campaign contributions]] under the terms of the [[Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission|''Citizens United'']] Supreme Court decision.<ref name="wapo"/>
Restore Our Future was founded by Romney aides in 2010.<ref name="la-times">{{cite news | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | title = Pro-Romney 'super PAC' reports $12-million haul | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jul/05/news/la-pn-romney-fundraising-20110705 | date = July 5, 2011 | accessdate = August 4, 2011 | first = Melanie | last = Mason}}</ref> Charles Spies, the group's treasurer and former [[general counsel]] for Romney's 2008 campaign for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential nomination, described Restore Our Future as "an independent effort focused on getting Romney elected president."<ref name="wapo">{{cite news | work = [[The Washington Post]] | title = Romney backers launch 'super PAC' to raise and spend unlimited amounts | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/romney-backers-launch-super-pac/2011/06/22/AGTkGchH_story.html | accessdate = August 4, 2011 | date = June 23, 2011 | first = Dan | last = Eggen | first2 = Chris| last2 = Cillizza}}</ref> The group reported raising over $12 million in the first half of 2011, in the form of large donations from approximately 90 wealthy individuals and corporations.<ref name="politico">{{cite news | work = [[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] | title = PAC brings in $12.2 million for Mitt | url = http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0711/60329.html | date = July 31, 2011 | accessdate = August 4, 2011 | first = Jonathan | last = Martin | first2 = Kenneth P. | last2= Vogel}}</ref> As of July 2012, Restore Our Future had raised more than $60 million,<ref name="byo">http://buyingyourfuture.org {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161014051539/http://www.buyingyourfuture.org/ |date=2016-10-14 }}</ref> nearly half from [[Wall Street]] contributors.<ref name='NYT_2012-05-02'>{{cite news | first = Nicholas | last = Confessore | title = Obama’s Not-So-Hot Date With Wall Street | date = 2012-05-02 | publisher = | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/06/magazine/obamas-not-so-hot-date-with-wall-street.html | work = [[The New York Times]] | accessdate = 2012-05-03}}</ref> Spies declined to discuss specific contributors to the PAC.<ref name="usa-today">{{cite news | work = [[USA Today]] | url= https://www.usatoday.com/NEWS/usaedition/2011-08-04-SuperPacs_ST_U.htm | title = Dozen donors spend big on '12 races | first = Fredreka | last = Schouten | accessdate = August 4, 2011 | date = August 4, 2011}}</ref>
== Contributors ==
As of July 2012, Restore Our Future had raised more than $60 million,<ref name="byo"/> a large portion of which came from Wall Street contributors.<ref name='NYT_2012-05-02'/>
{{As of|August 2011}}, the largest individual contributor to Restore Our Future was [[John Paulson]], a billionaire and [[hedge fund]] manager who is, according to ''[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]]'', "famous for [having enriched] himself by betting on the collapse of the housing industry."<ref name="politico"/> An additional million dollars came from [[W Spann LLC]], a [[dummy corporation]] with no record of actual business activities.<ref name="wapo-concerns">{{cite news | work = The [[Washington Post]] | title = Mystery firm’s $1M donation to pro-Romney PAC raises concern over transparency | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/short-lived-firms-1m-donation-to-gop-fund-raises-concern-over-transparency/2011/08/04/gIQAvczruI_story.html | first = Dan | last = Eggen | date = August 4, 2011 | accessdate = August 7, 2011}}</ref> W Spann LLC was incorporated, donated to the PAC, and then dissolved in a matter of months,<ref name="msnbc">{{cite news | publisher = [[msnbc.com]] | url = http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/44011308/ns/politics-decision_2012/ | title = Firm gives $1 million to pro-Romney group, then dissolves | first = Michael | last = Isikoff | authorlink = Michael Isikoff | accessdate = August 4, 2011}}</ref><ref name="nyt">{{cite news | work = [[The New York Times]] | title = Donation to Romney-Tied Group Draws Scrutiny | accessdate = August 4, 2011 |authorlink=Nicholas Confessore | first = Nicholas | last = Confessore | url = http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/04/donation-to-romney-tied-group-draws-scrutiny/ | date = August 4, 2011}}</ref> attracting concern from election-watchdog groups and campaign-finance experts about the use of [[dummy corporation]]s to shield large campaign contributions from public scrutiny.<ref name="wapo-concerns"/>
Several watchdog groups requested that the [[U.S. Department of Justice|Justice Department]] and [[Federal Election Commission]] investigate donations to Restore Our Future from W Spann LLC as possible violations of campaign-finance law.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news | publisher = [[Reuters]] | title = Watchdogs seek source of money to Romney backer | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/05/us-usa-campaign-finance-romney-idUSTRE7746JP20110805 | date = August 5, 2011 | accessdate = August 7, 2011 | first= Molly | last = O'Toole}}</ref> Restore Our Future declined to provide additional details about the donation and asserted that it had complied with existing laws.
In response to rumors, a spokesman for [[Bain Capital]], a [[private equity firm]] previously headed by Romney, stated that W Spann LLC "is not affiliated with Bain Capital or any of our employees."<ref name="wapo-concerns"/> Shortly thereafter, Edward Conard, a former top executive at Bain Capital who retired in 2007, came forward to state that he had formed W Spann LLC and funded and authorized the $1 million contribution.<ref name="ap-donor-id">{{cite news | publisher= [[Associated Press]] | title = Mysterious donor to pro-Romney PAC identified | url = https://news.yahoo.com/mysterious-donor-pro-romney-pac-identified-160307460.html | date = August 6, 2011 | accessdate = August 7, 2011 | first = Jack | last = Gillum}}</ref> Conard requested that Restore Our Future amend its filings to reflect that he, rather than W Spann LLC, had donated the $1 million.<ref name="hill-id">{{cite news | work= [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | first = Alexander | last = Burton | url = http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/fundraising/175765-mystery-romney-supporter-reveals-himself-after-watchdog-groups-call-for-investigation | title = Mystery Romney backer reveals himself | accessdate = August 7, 2011 | date = August 6, 2011}}</ref><ref name="poltico-id">{{cite news | work = [[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] | title = Mystery Mitt Romney donor comes forward | url = http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0811/60776.html | first = Maggie | last = Haberman | accessdate=August 7, 2011 | date = August 5, 2011}}</ref>
Another entity, [[Paumanok Partners LLC]], contributed $250,000 to Restore Our Future. It has been traced back to Romney donor [[William Laverack, Jr.]]<ref name="nyt-donor-id-1">{{cite news | work = [[The New York Times]]| title = THE CAUCUS; A Likely Name For a Mystery Donor | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F04E4DC163AF930A35751C0A9649D8B63 | first = Michael | last = Luo | accessdate=February 14, 2012 | date = February 3, 2012}}</ref> [[Glenbrook L.L.C.]] was originally reported as donating $250,000 in August 2011, but in an amended filing with the FEC the Glenbrook donation was replaced by two $125,000 donations by Jesse Rogers, a former executive at Bain & Company.<ref name="nyt-donor-id-2">{{cite news | work = [[The New York Times]]| title = A Secret Donor Revealed | url = http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/07/a-secret-donor-revealed/ | first = Michael | last = Luo | accessdate=February 14, 2012 | date = February 7, 2012}}</ref>
Two additional $1 million contributions came from corporations registered to the offices of two executives of [[Nu Skin Enterprises]], a Utah-based [[multilevel marketing]] company selling skin-care products and [[dietary supplements]].<ref name="politico"/> Other large contributors included members of the Marriott family, hedge-fund managers, and investors in Bain Capital.<ref name="politico"/>
Several Affiliates of Melaleuca, Inc., an Idaho-based multilevel marketing<ref>{{cite web|last=Berman|first=Phyllis|title=Forbes.com If You Believe|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2004/1011/089.html|publisher=Forbes.com}}</ref> company owned by [[Frank L. VanderSloot]], have donated a total of approx. $1 million to the PAC.<ref name=motherjones>{{cite web|last=Mencimer|first=Stephanie|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/02/mitt-romney-melaleuca-frank-vandersloot|title=Pyramid-Like Company Ponies Up $1 Million for Mitt Romney|publisher=Mother Jones|accessdate=2012}}</ref> VanderSloot is also a national finance co-chairman of the Romney campaign.<ref>{{cite web|last=Confessore|first=Nicholas|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/01/us/politics/campaign-finance-reports-show-super-pac-donors.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|title=G.O.P. Donors Showing Thirst to Oust Obama in November|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=May 2012|date=2012-01-31}}</ref>
===From federal contractors=== Despite a 36-year-old ban against [[federal contractor]]s making federal political expenditures, Restore Our Future has accepted donations of $890,000 from at least five such companies, who are taking advantage of a legal gray area created by the [[U.S. Supreme Court]]'s 2010 ruling in [[Citizens United v. FEC]]. [[Oxbow Carbon]], a major coal and petroleum company founded by [[Bill Koch (businessman)|William Koch]] that contracts with the [[Tennessee Valley Authority]], gave $750,000, and has insisted such donations are now legal. Another company, [[M.C. Dean]], a Virginia-based electrical engineering company, donated $5,000, but has asked the funds to be returned after consulting with lawyers. The other companies are: [[B/E Aerospace]], a [[U.S. Department of Defense]] contractor, which gave $50,000; [[Clinical Medical Services]], which contracts with the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Department of Veterans Affairs]], donated $25,000; and [[Suffolk Construction Co.]], which is building a [[U.S. Naval]] base, donated $60,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-contractor-politics-20120318,0,7570089,full.story |title=Federal contractors donate to 'super PAC' backing Romney |publisher=Los Angeles Times |date=2012-03-18 |first=Ian |last=Duncan |author2=[[Matea Gold]] }}</ref>
==Iowa ad== In December 2011, [[Glenn Kessler (journalist)|Glenn Kessler]] of the ''Washington Post'' found that a Restore ad attacking [[Newt Gingrich]] in [[Iowa Republican caucuses, 2012|Iowa]] had a number of "egregious fouls" and "underhanded" treatment of [[Newt Gingrich presidential campaign, 2012#Top tier candidate|Freddie Mac]] and [[Political positions of Newt Gingrich#Abortion|abortion]] issues. The PAC had $3 million budgeted for the Iowa television campaign. Brittany Gross, a Restore spokesperson, declined to answer questions from Kessler about the ad.<ref>Kessler, Glenn, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/romney-versus-gingrich-a-super-pacs-over-the-top-ad/2011/12/20/gIQAeJQn7O_blog.html "Romney versus Gingrich: a Super PAC’s over-the-top ad"], ''Washington Post'' Fact Checker blog, 12/21/2011 06:02 am ET. Retrieved 2011-12-21.</ref>
==Board and staffing== Restore’s board of directors included treasurer Spies; [[Carl Forti]], political director for Governor Romney’s 2008 campaign and of [[American Crossroads]] Super PAC; and [[Larry McCarthy]], a member of Governor Romney's media team in 2008.<ref name="wapo"/>
Don Stirling, who was the [[2002 Winter Olympics#Bribery to bring the games to Salt Lake City|2002 Utah Olympics]]' local marketing chief and fundraiser working with Romney, worked with Restore Our Future during [[Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012|Governor Romney's 2012 presidential campaign]].<ref>[[Jim Rutenberg|Rutenberg, Jim]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/17/us/politics/support-for-romney-by-old-mormon-families.html?pagewanted=3&_r=1&hp "Mormons’ First Families Rally Behind Romney"], ''The New York Times'', web p. 3, July 16, 2012. Retrieved 2012-07-17.</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120717041025/http://restoreourfuture.com/ Official web site]
[[Category:United States political action committees]] [[Category:Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012]] [[Category:Campaign finance in the United States]] [[Category:2010 establishments in the United States]]

{{about||the usage in computer science|First-class citizen|the commonly confused term|Less-than-whole citizens}} {{legal status}} {{Sociology}} {{Rights |By claimant}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} A '''second-class citizen''' is a person who is systematically [[discrimination|discriminated]] against within a [[State (polity)|state]] or other [[Political division|political jurisdiction]], despite their nominal status as a citizen or legal resident there. While not necessarily [[slaves]], [[civil death|outlaws]] or [[criminals]], second-class citizens have limited legal rights, civil rights and socioeconomic opportunities, and are often subject to mistreatment or neglect at the hands of their putative superiors. However, they are different from "[[less-than-whole citizens]]",{{Cite book|title=Fragmented Citizens: The Changing Landscape of Gay and Lesbian Lives|last=Engel|first=Stephen|publisher=NYU Press|year=2016|isbn=1479809128|location=|pages=}} as second-class citizens are often disregarded by the law or have it used to [[harassment|harass]] them (see [[police misconduct]] and [[racial profiling]]). Systems with ''[[de facto]]'' second-class citizenry are generally regarded as violating human rights.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/second-class-citizen|title=the definition of second-class citizen|website=Dictionary.com|access-date=2017-05-11}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/second-class%20citizen|title=Definition of SECOND-CLASS CITIZEN|website=www.merriam-webster.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-11}} Typical conditions facing second-class citizens include but are not limited to: * [[disenfranchisement]] (a lack or loss of voting rights) * limitations on [[civil service|civil]] or [[military]] service (not including [[conscription]] in every case) * restrictions on [[language]], [[religion]], [[education]] * lack of freedom of movement and association * limitations on weapons ownership * restrictions on [[marriage]] * restrictions on [[Gender Identity|gender identity and expression]] * restrictions on [[House|housing]] * restrictions on [[property|property ownership]] The category is normally unofficial and mostly academic, and the term itself is generally used as a [[pejorative]] and governments will typically deny the existence of a second class within the [[polity]]. As an informal category, second-class citizenship is not objectively measured; however, cases such as the [[American South]] under [[Racial segregation|segregation]], [[Aboriginal Australians|aborigines]] in [[Australia]] prior to 1967, [[apartheid]] in [[Republic of South Africa|South Africa]], [[Women's rights in Saudi Arabia|women]] in [[Saudi Arabia]] under Saudi law, [[Dalit]]s in [[India]] and [[Nepal]], and [[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholics]] in [[Northern Ireland]] during the [[Parliament of Northern Ireland|parliamentary]] era are all examples of groups that have been historically described as having second-class citizenry. Historically, before the mid-20th century, this policy was applied by some European [[Colonial empire|Colonial Empires]] on colonial [[Domicile (law)|residents]] of overseas holdings. A [[resident alien]] or [[foreign national]], and [[children]] in general, fit most definitions of second-class citizen. This does not mean that they do not have any legal protections, nor do they lack acceptance by the local population.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/second-class-citizen|title=the definition of second-class citizen|website=Dictionary.com|access-date=2017-05-12}} A [[naturalized]] citizen carries essentially the same rights and responsibilities as any other citizen (a possible exception being ineligibility for certain public offices), and is also legally protected. == Relationship with citizenry class == {| class="wikitable" !'''Citizenry class''' !Freedoms !Limitations !Legal status |- |[[Citizenship|Full and equal citizenship]] |Freedom to reside and work, freedom to enter and leave the country, freedom to vote, freedom to stand for public office, |No limitations |
Internationally recognized
|- |[[Less-than-whole citizens]]hip |All the freedoms above with limitations on: [[Civil service|civil]] or [[military]] service opportunities, limitations on [[Freedom of movement|freedom of movement and association]] and [[marriage]]. |Partially limited |
Internationally recognized
|- |Second-class citizenry |Restrictions on freedom of [[language]], [[religion]], [[education]], and [[Property|property ownership]], and other [[Materialism|material or social needs]]. |Largely limited |
Internationally recognized
|- |[[Alien (law)|Non-citizens]] |Rights are neither given nor withdrawn from the individual. |Non-Assessable |
Internationally recognized
|- | Outlaws, criminals |No rights to outlaws, or criminals in normal citizenry classes, however, certain countries have constitutional sets and legal standards for criminals and outlaws |Completely limited |
[[Slavery|Widely unrecognized]]
|} ==Examples== * Proposals for a U.S. [[guest worker program]]—which would provide legal status to and admit foreign workers to the U.S., but provide no path to citizenship for them—has been criticized on the ground that such a policy would creating second-class non-citizens.{{cite web|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/thats-hospitality |title=That's Hospitality | New Republic|magazine=[[The New Republic]]|date=April 17, 2006}}[[Conor Friedersdorf]], [https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2013/01/reform-immigration-but-dont-create-second-class-non-citizens/267277/ Reform Immigration, but Don't Create Second-Class Non-Citizens], ''The Atlantic'' (January 17, 2013).Anna Stilz, [https://scholar.princeton.edu/sites/default/files/Stilz_guestworker_0.pdf Guestworkers and second-class citizenship], ''Policy and Society'', Vol. 29, Issue 4 (November 2010), pp. 295–307. * [[Non-citizens (Latvia)|Latvian non-citizens]] constitute a group similar to second-class citizens.{{cite web|url=http://www.neurope.eu/article/walk-latvian|title='Walk like a Latvian'|publisher=New Europe|date=2013-06-01|accessdate=2013-10-03}} Although they are not considered foreigners (they hold no other citizenship, have Latvian IDs), they have reduced rights compared to full citizens. For example, non-citizens are not eligible to vote or hold public office. The [[European Commission against Racism and Intolerance]] has described their status as making "people concerned feel like “second-class citizens”.[http://hudoc.ecri.coe.int/XMLEcri/ENGLISH/Cycle_03/03_CbC_eng/LVA-CbC-III-2008-2-ENG.pdf Third report on Latvia. CRI(2008)2] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509044128/http://hudoc.ecri.coe.int/XMLEcri/ENGLISH/Cycle_03/03_CbC_eng/LVA-CbC-III-2008-2-ENG.pdf |date=2009-05-09 }} Executive summary Estonian non-citizens are in a similar position. * New Zealanders receive automatically a "[[Special Category Visa]]" upon entering Australia, which presents no pathway to Australian citizenship. New Zealanders are denied access to [[Centrelink]], to name just one of the services. This means that if, for example, a New Zealand person came to Australia to live with his or her Australian spouse, and that spouse committed domestic violence upon them, the New Zealander could not then turn to Centrelink to provide them with funds to leave the abusive spouse. * Mainland Chinese citizens who are settling in Hong Kong or Macau by means of a [[one-way permit]] do not have citizenship rights (such as obtaining a [[passport]]) in both the mainland or the SAR after settling but before obtaining the permanent resident status, effectively rendering them second-class citizens. * [[Burakumin]] (部落民) is a designation of Japanese Second-class status meaning the people who are from a place called a "buraku." “Buraku” basically means a village or small district. For a long time, people have discriminated against people from a "buraku" even though they belong to the same [[Race (human categorization)|race]], and there are no differences between ordinary [[Japanese people|Japanese]] people and people who are called burakumin. It is not clear when and why this started, but it is said that it was most common in the [[Edo period]].{{cite book|last1=Roth|first1=Louis Frédéric ; translated by Käthe|title=Japan encyclopedia|date=2005|publisher=Belknap|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=9780674017535|pages=93–94|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA93#v=onepage&q&f=false}} They are often called "eta" (穢多) or "[[hinin]]" (非人) meaning polluted or not a human. Even though in [[Meiji 4]] (1871), this discrimination was officially ended by kaihourei ([[:ja:解放令|解放令]]), many people resisted it and continued treating them as burakumin. Today, fewer people are discriminate towards burakumin, however, the term burakumin is still recognized as a discriminating word while there are certain amount of recent young generations who do not even know the term and idea of burakumin. Also, in some cases, people still happen to be discriminated against, especially when they get a job or get married.{{cite web|last1=Saito (齋藤）|first1=Naoko(直子)|title=部落出身者と結婚差別|website=http://synodos.jp/society/10900}} These cases often reported as problems. * Natives of many colonized lands in the past could be considered second-class citizens compared to the colonists, however as generations pass on they become "[[Less-than-whole citizens]]" unless dramatic citizenship rights are ensured. ==See also== *[[Blacklisting]] *[[Dégradation nationale]] *[[Involuntary unemployment]] *[[Loss of rights due to felony conviction]] *[[Less-than-whole citizens|"Less-than-whole" citizens]] ==References== {{Reflist}}{{Segregation by type}} {{Nationality laws}} {{Social class}} {{Human rights |organizations=yes |legal=yes |rights=yes }} {{Abuse}} {{Discrimination}} [[Category:Discrimination]] [[Category:Equality rights]] [[Category:Human rights abuses]] [[Category:Injustice]] [[Category:Political terminology]] [[Category:Prejudice and discrimination]] [[Category:Religion and politics]] [[Category:Social inequality]] [[Category:Social groups]]

[[File:Sosialistiki Ergatiki Omospondia (Federacion).jpg|thumb|Socialist Workers' Federation (Φεντερασιόν in Greek). The official application with which the part is asking from the Greek court authority for recognition in 1916.]]
The '''Socialist Workers' Federation''' ({{lang-fr|Fédération Socialiste Ouvrière}}, {{lang-lad|Federacion}}, {{lang-tr|Selanik Sosyalist İşçi Federasyonu}}), was a socialist organisation in the [[Salonica Vilayet]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]] (present-day [[Thessaloniki]]), led by [[Avraam Benaroya]]. It was an attempt at union of different nationalities' workers in [[Thessaloniki|Salonica]] within a single labor movement.
==The Federation in the Ottoman Empire== [[File:Benaroya1914.jpg|thumb|left|160px|[[Avraam Benaroya]]]] [[File:Workers March in Salonica 1908 - 1909.jpg|thumb|Jewish workers march, 1908 - 1909]]
Idealistic and pragmatist at the same time, [[Avraam Benaroya]], a [[Jew]] from [[Bulgaria]], played a leading role in the creation of the mainly Jewish ''Fédération Socialiste Ouvrière'' in Thessaloniki, in May–June 1909.<ref>Nar, Alberto: [http://www.intjewishlawyers.org/docenter/viewDocument.asp?id=9266 "The Jew of Thessaloniki March through Time"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060627075049/http://www.intjewishlawyers.org/docenter/viewDocument.asp?id=9266 |date=2006-06-27 }}, in ''Justice. The International Association of Jewish Lawyers and Jurists'', special issue: ''Remember Salonika'' (Spring 1999). ISSN 0793-176X. pp. 9-13.</ref> His main associates were militant [[Sephardic Jews]], Alberto Arditti, David Recanati and Joseph Hazan, as well Bulgarians like Angel Tomov and [[Dimitar Vlahov]].
The organization took this name because, built on the federative model of the [[Social Democratic Party of Austria]], it was conceived as a federation of separate sections, each representing the four main ethnic groups of the city: [[Jew]]s, [[Bulgarians]], [[Greeks]] and [[Turkish people|Turks]]. It initially published its literature in the languages of these four groups (i.e. Ladino, [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Greek language|Greek]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]], respectively) but in practice the two latter sections were under-represented if not nonexistent. The publication's title was ''Journal del Labourador'' (Ladino) - ''Amele Gazetesi'' (Ottoman Turkish).
The democratic ''Fédération'' soon became, under Benaroya's leadership, the strongest [[Socialism|socialist party]] in the [[Ottoman Empire]], while the "[[Ottoman Socialist Party]]" was essentially an intellectual club, and the other socialist parties were at the same time national parties, like the [[Istanbul]] Greek Socialist Center, the [[Social Democrat Hunchakian Party]] or the [[Armenian Revolutionary Federation]].<ref name="hur">{{cite news|url=http://www.taraf.com.tr/makale/601.htm|title=Cumhuriyet’in Amele Evlatları!|last=Hür|first=Ayşe|date=April 24, 2008|publisher=[[Taraf]]|language=Turkish|accessdate=2009-11-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521160213/http://www.taraf.com.tr/makale/601.htm|archivedate=May 21, 2009|df=}}</ref> It created combative trade unions, attracted important intellectuals and gained a solid base of support among Macedonian workers. By 1910, the ''Fédération'' comprised fourteen syndicates, and in 1912 it mobilized about 12,000 workers in various demonstrations.<ref>{{cite book|last=Quataert|first=Donald|title=The Industrial working class of Salonica, 1850-1912 (in Jews, Turks, Ottomans: a shared history, fifteenth through the twentieth century)|editor=Levy, Avigdor|publisher=Syracuse University Press|year=2002|pages=395|isbn=978-0-8156-2941-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3lRkp8Oes18C&pg=PA210|accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref> From 1910 to 1911 Benaroya edited its influential newspaper, the ''[[Solidaridad Ovradera]]'', printed in Ladino. ''Fédération'' cultivated strong links with the [[Second International]] and had its own representative, Saul Nahum, in the [[International Socialist Bureau]].
Unlike other parties which were organised on ethnic lines, as a cross-community group the ''Fédération'' was tolerated by the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] authorities. A prominent Bulgarian member, [[Dimitar Vlahov]], was a socialist MP in the [[Second Constitutional Era (Ottoman Empire)|new Ottoman parliament]], which was dominated by the [[Committee of Union and Progress]] (CUP) party until 1912. Indeed, its leaders initially supported the [[Young Turks]], and Benaroya participated in the "Action Army" march on [[Istanbul]] to help put down the [[Countercoup (1909)|Countercoup of 1909]]. Alarmed by the growing power of socialist groups, the CUP subsequently launched a crackdown, during which Benaroya was jailed.<ref>[[Mark Mazower]], ''Salonica city of ghosts'', Vintage Books, New York, 2005. {{ISBN|978-0-375-41298-1}} pp. 288f.</ref>
In their reference book over the Balkan Jews, [[Esther Benbassa]] and Aron Rodrigues show that the internationalist socialists of the ''Fédération'' defended the Ladino language against the [[Zionism|Zionists]], favouring [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], and the ''[[Alliance Israélite Universelle]]'', who favoured French, thus remaining in some way close to the traditional Jewish world, they represented a form of westernization without assimilation.<ref>{{lang-fr|''Les AA (''auteurs'') montrent comment en défendant la langue judéo-espagnole (contre les sionistes partisans de hébreu ou les francophones de l'Alliance) les socialistes internationalistes de la Fédération restaient en dernière analyse assez proches du monde juif traditionnel: ils représentaient une forme d'occidentalisation qui impliquait pas l'assimilation''|italic=unset}}, Löwy Michael, ''[http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/assr_0335-5985_1994_num_86_1_1443_t1_0265_0000_4 Benbassa (Esther) Rodrigue (Aron) Juifs des Balkans. Espaces judéo-ibériques XIV-XXe siècles]'' (review), Archives des sciences sociales des religions, 1994, vol. 86, n° 1, pp. 265-266. Accessed on November 14, 2009</ref>
== The Federation and the labour movement in Greece == [[File:Socialist Workers' Federation doc 1915.jpg|thumb|Socialist Workers' Federation (Φεντερασιόν in Greek). The official application with which the party is asking for recognition of the socialist youth in 1915.]]
In the aftermath of the incorporation of Thessaloniki into the Greek state during the [[Balkan Wars]], Benaroya resisted the attempts to impose ethnic divisions in the city. Opposed to the [[First World War]], Benaroya and another Jewish socialist were exiled for two and a half years at the island of [[Naxos (island)|Naxos]]. In contrast to most of the prominent socialists in the pre-1913 Greece who followed [[Eleftherios Venizelos]], Benaroya and the ''Fédération'', adhering to its internationalist ideals, mobilized for [[Neutral country|neutrality]]. As this happened to the same policy as pursued by King [[Constantine I of Greece]] and his militaristic entourage (see [[National Schism]]), this led to the loss of support for ''Fédération'' in [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonia]]. After the departure of its Slavic element, the ''Fédération'' was numerically dominated by Jews.<ref>Benbassa, Esther: "Le sionisme dans l'Empire ottoman à l'aube du XXe siècle", in: XXe Siècle., n°24, oct. 1989, p. 74</ref>
From 1915 onwards the ''Fédération'' was buoyed by the popular reaction to the war. Both [[Monarchy|monarchist]] and Venizelist policy actually assisted the emancipation and the radicalization of the left, and Benaroya, keeping equal distance from both established political groups, was quick to turn the situation to advantage. In the [[Greek legislative election, May 1915|May 1915 general elections]] the ''Fédération'' sent two deputies representing Thessaloniki to the Greek Parliament, while it lost by only a few votes for a third seat. It already had strong links with internationalist groups and organizations all over Greece and abroad; from them the [[Communist Party of Greece|Socialist Workers' Party]] was to spring up in due time.<ref>Benbassa, Esther, and Rodrigue, Aaron: ''Historia de los judíos sefardíes. De Toledo a Salónica''. Abada, Madrid, 2004 {{ISBN|84-96258-31-9}}, pp. 308-310.</ref> However, another socialist faction, headed by the future Prime Minister [[Alexandros Papanastasiou]], who sided with Venizelos in foreign affairs, also had deputies elected in the same election.
Papanastasiou and other reform-minded socialists strongly supported Venizelos' liberal brand of nationalism. Benaroya and the ''Fédération'', on the other hand, were influenced by [[Austromarxism|Austromarxists]] such as [[Victor Adler]], [[Otto Bauer]] and [[Karl Renner]], who, sensitive to matters national, searched ways to utilize socialism as a cohesive force for the decrepit [[Habsburg Monarchy]]; they elaborated the [[National personal autonomy|principle of personal autonomy]], according to which national consciousness should be depoliticized and become a personal matter. Modern states should be based on free association and allow self-definition and self-organization of ethnicities in cultural affairs, while a mixed parliament, proportionally representing all nations of the realm, should decide on economic and political questions. The ''Fédération'' traced the origins of its federative position in Balkan authors of the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] like [[Rigas Velestinlis-Fereos|Rigas Velestinlis]], and stressed that the forthcoming peace should exclude any change of borders or transfer of populations. The [[SEKE|Socialist Labour Party of Greece]] (later renamed as Communist Party of Greece, KKE), created by Benaroya's initiative near the end of the [[First World War]], followed closely the ''Fédération'''s theses on national [[self-determination]], and wanted to transform the Greek state into a federation of [[Autonomous region|autonomous provinces]] that would safeguard the rights of minorities and participate in a federative Republic of the Balkan peoples.
== References == {{reflist|2}}
==Sources== * [https://www.marxists.org/subject/jewish/salonica.pdf H. Şükrü Ilicak (September 2002). "Jewish Socialism in Ottoman Salonica"]. Southeast European and Black Sea Studies. 2 (3): 115–146. ISSN 1468-3857 * [https://ojs.lib.uom.gr/index.php/BalkanStudies/article/download/3059/3083 Iakovos J. Aktsoglou, ''The emergence / development of social and working class movement in the city of Thessaloniki (working associations and labor unions)''], “Balkan Studies”, Thessaloniki, Vol. 38, No. 2, 1997, pp. 285-306. * [https://www.jstor.org/pss/4464788 Joshua Starr, ''The Socialist Federation of Saloniki'', Jewish Social Studies, Vol. 7, No. 4 (Oct. 1945), pp. 323-336] * [https://www.jstor.org/stable/4464788 Abraham Benaroya, ''A Note on "The Socialist Federation of Saloniki"'', Jewish Social Studies, Vol. 11, No. 1 (Jan. 1949), pp. 69-72] * Nicole Cohen-Rak, ''La "Solidaridad ovradera", journal socialiste judéo-espagnol de Salonique, 1911: édition de 7 numéros, traductions, index divers, considérations linguistiques'', Vol. 1 and 2, Université de Paris III, 1986.

revision.comment: [[WP:CHECKWIKI]] error fix. Section heading problem. Violates [[WP:MOSHEAD]].
revision.text:
'''Status Quo State''' is a term from [[Power Transition Theory]] within the wider field of [[International Relations]]. It is used to describe states, that unlike [[Revisionist State]]s see the international system of states, international law and often even free market economics as integral aspects of the international spectrum that should be upheld.
Written on [https://books.google.co.kr/books?hl=en&lr=&id=tbgYDAAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PR7&dq=The+Origins+of+Revisionist+and+Status-Quo+States+By+J.+Davidson&ots=2Mv5V4SA_I&sig=DJkWBQqlx5iD-sVrFkTC0wFSWEU&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=The%20Origins%20of%20Revisionist%20and%20Sta The Origins of Revisionist and Status-Quo States by J. Davidson], status-quo state seekers strive to preserve things as they are. Whereas revisionists seek to change the way things are in international politics. When scholars categorize states as revisionist or status-quo seeking they are able to explain important outcomes in international politics, such as war and peace.
Generally, there is a direct correlation between a state's hegemony, both political and economic and its standing as either a Status Quo State or a Revisionist State.<ref>[http://www.hawaii.edu/intlrel/pols315/Text/Theory/PowerTransitionTheory.htm Power Transition Theory, summary. Richard W. Chadwick<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Powerful and influential nations in International Relations such as the [[United Kingdom]], [[France]] and other nations like [[Japan]] who have benefited from western liberalism, are likely to fall under the category of ''Status Quo States'', while [[North Korea]], [[Iran]] and other nations dissatisfied with their place on the international stage are often considered Revisionist States.
== Characteristic of Status-quo state == A system consisting mostly of status-quo states need not devolve into war. Moreover, if status-quo states recognize each other as such and are not threatened by each other, they should be confronted with fewer cooperation-inhibiting problems (e.g., [[Relative gain (international relations)|relative gains]] concerns) than they would if they feared others’ intentions.
The author mentions that according to the neoclassical realist framework, it points toward “new facts,” where they explain that periods of “concert” can occur when all or most states are committed to preserving the status quo. The author also explains this with the example of [https://www.britannica.com/event/Concert-of-Europe the Concert of Europe (1815-54)] where states were able to hold those norms and follow those rules because they were status-quo seekers and understood that their neighbors were also committed to the status quo.
Revisionist and status-quo states have been the core of the history of international relations. As the history of [[great power]] war and peace may be seen as a series of clashes between revisionists and status-quo seekers. Moreover, Status-quo states may ally with the most powerful state in the system if it is also a status-quo state, because they should not fear such a state and because they prefer to have defensive coalitions that are too large rather than too small.
==See also== *[[Power transition theory]] *[[Revisionist State]] *[[International relations]]
==References== {{Reflist}}2. [https://books.google.co.kr/books?hl=en&lr=&id=tbgYDAAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PR7&dq=The+Origins+of+Revisionist+and+Status-Quo+States+By+J.+Davidson&ots=2Mv5V4SA_I&sig=DJkWBQqlx5iD-sVrFkTC0wFSWEU&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=The%20Origins%20of%20Revisionist%20and%20Sta Davidson, J. (2016). ''The origins of revisionist and status-quo states''. Springer.]
3. [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03050629608434886 Lemke, D., & Reed, W. (1996). Regime types and status quo evaluations: Power transition theory and the democratic peace. ''International Interactions'', ''22''(2), 143-164.]
4. [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1057/palgrave.jors.2601870?casa_token=XVnefc8wYMMAAAAA:hJt5VqX-hUt805wmtObnZG64NBVKdH6pqjgI2s-H1NdfumIN4vYIoMxeU3eW5Q1uSZl2L1YZCPBL-g Li, K. W., Kilgour, D. M., & Hipel, K. W. (2005). Status quo analysis in the graph model for conflict resolution. ''Journal of the Operational Research Society'', ''56''(6), 699-707.] [[Category:International relations terminology]] [[Category:States by power status]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} [[File:Tony Blair.jpg|thumb|350px|Some people appointed to positions of power by Tony Blair were called "Tony's Cronies"]] "'''Tony's Cronies'''" is a term in British politics and media given to people who were viewed as being given positions of power because of their personal friendships with [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Tony Blair]], during his [[Premiership of Tony Blair|premiership]] between 1997 and 2007.<ref name=eco>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/230423 |title=The new establishment: Tony’s cronies? |work=The Economist |date=1999-08-05 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> These included those granted life peerages and public positions based on their friendship with Blair rather than their individual merits.<ref name=ncc /> The phrase was created by the [[Conservative Party (United Kingdom)|Conservative Party]] after the [[1997 United Kingdom general election]] and was continually used in the media throughout Blair's premiership.
== History == The term originated after the 1997 United Kingdom general election when the Conservative Party referred to people awarded positions of power by Tony Blair as "Tony's Cronies", as the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] had won the election.<ref name=eco /> These people were compared to medieval courtiers, viewed to have been appointed to positions of power because of their historical personal background with Blair. [[Lord Irvine]], appointed [[Lord Chancellor]], was Blair's first boss; whilst [[Anji Hunter]], who had been at school with Blair, was made Blair's office manager.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/1999/jan/05/uk.politicalnews1 |title=Tony's cronies: the inner circle of power |work=The Guardian |date=1999-01-05 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> His childhood friend and former flatmate, [[Charlie Falconer]], was appointed as a peer, sat on 14 [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet]] sub-committees and later joined the Cabinet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/2984844.stm |title=UK | Lordly heights for Blair's friend |publisher=BBC News |date=2003-06-12 |accessdate=2014-08-04}}</ref>
=== House of Lords ===
During his first term of office, Blair created 203 [[life peers]], whom the Conservatives referred to as "Tony's Cronies".<ref>{{cite news|last=Jones |first=George |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1351595/Life-in-the-Lords-is-too-tough-says-Labour-peer.html |title=Life in the Lords is too tough says Labour peer |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=2000-08-05 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> In 1999, [[William Hague]], the [[Leader of the Conservative Party (UK)|Leader of the Conservative Party]] and the [[Leader of the Opposition (United Kingdom)|Leader of the Opposition]], referred in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] to the [[House of Lords Act 1999|House of Lords Bill]], as replacing the [[House of Lords]] with a "house of cronies."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199899/cmhansrd/vo981124/debtext/81124-05.htm |title=House of Commons Hansard Debates for 24 Nov 1998 (pt 5) |work=Hansard |date=1998-11-24 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> When the bill was passed, it removed the rights of [[hereditary peers]] to sit in the House of Lords; they were replaced by life peers and the House of Lords was called "a chamber of Tony's Cronies", as a large number of life peers had been appointed by Blair to replace the hereditary peers.<ref>{{cite news|first=Colin |last=Brown |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/parliament-house-of-lords--rearguard-action-against-chamber-of-tonys-cronies-1125057.html |title=Rearguard action against chamber of "Tony's cronies" |work=The Independent |date=1999-11-11 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> However, while the bill was going through the Parliamentary stages, the Conservative hereditary peers voted through an amendment that an independent body, which became known as the [[House of Lords Appointments Commission]], would be created to check all further nominations to the House of Lords. This was intended to prevent the Prime Minister from being able to create new life peers at will or on personal grounds.<ref>{{cite news|first=Michael |last=White |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/1999/jun/23/lordreform.constitution |title=Peers toughen body to stop 'Tony's cronies' safeguard |work=The Guardian |date= 2001-03-21|accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> It also made the provision for "[[people's peers]]" to be created, independent of political influence, which was viewed in the media as a way to balance against "Tony's Cronies".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/People's+peers+to+combat+Tony's+cronies.-a060487421 |title=People's peers to combat Tony's cronies. |publisher=Coventry Evening Telegraph (archived at The Free Library) |date=1999-01-20 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
Despite the House of Lords Act removing a large number of Conservative Peers, the Conservatives still held a majority in that body, leading Blair to appoint additional peers; in 2004 alone he made 23 new appointments.<ref>{{cite news|first=Patrick |last=Wintour |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/may/01/uk.lords |title=Blair appointees on mission impossible to stop defeats |work=The Guardian |date=2004-05-01 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> This came after Conservative peers sometimes voted with [[crossbenchers]] and [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] peers against Labour's proposed legislation. It was also due to poor attendance from the Labour Party's [[working peers]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Brogan |first=Benedict |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1460743/Tonys-cronies-pack-into-Lords.html |title=Tony's cronies pack into Lords |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=2004-05-01 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> In 2005, Blair appointed 16 new life peers to the House of Lords, giving Labour their first ever majority in the House.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/tonys-cronies-to-give-labour-lords-majority-7169941.html |title=Tony's cronies to give Labour Lords majority |work=London Evening Standard |date=2005-04-29 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> These regular appointments of new peers on apparent favouritism was criticized by the [[Scottish National Party]]'s [[chief whip]], [[Pete Wishart]], as a "typical Establishment fix".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/tony-s-cronies-parachuted-in-as-new-labour-lords-1-529284 |title=Tony's cronies parachuted in as new Labour Lords |work=The Scotsman |date=2004-05-01 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
=== Other positions ===
The accusations of [[cronyism]] also extended to a number of public appointments Blair made. In 2001, the public administration [[select committee]] held an inquiry into the claims that the government rewarded "Tony's Cronies".<ref>{{cite news|last=Brogan |first=Benedict |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1362232/MPs-investigate-Tonys-cronies.html |title=MPs investigate 'Tony's cronies' |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=2001-11-13 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> In 2002, there were also accusations of cronyism from the Conservatives and the [[Mayor of London]], [[Ken Livingstone]], when Labour gave [[Lord Hollick]], a friend of Blair, the chairmanship of the [[South Bank Arts Complex]] as a personal gift. Labour rejected this claim, saying that the appointment was not covered by the public appointments guidelines.<ref name=ncc>{{cite news|last=Reynolds |first=Nigel |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1385296/New-crony-claims-rejected-by-Labour.html |title=New crony claims rejected by Labour |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=2002-02-19 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> The accusation of "Tony's Cronies" also extended to the [[European Union]] when Blair appointed [[Peter Mandelson]] as the UK's [[European Commissioner|European Union Commissioner]]. This move was criticised by members of the Labour party, with Labour [[Member of Parliament (UK)|MP]], [[Ian Davidson (British politician)|Ian Davidson]], saying that it was "... seen as arrogance by [[New Labour]], bringing in a crony of the Prime Minister who is deeply unpopular in the Labour Party."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/He's+not+crony+Blair%3A+Old+pals'+act%3B+Mandy+defends+his+new+Euro+job.-a0119725938 |title=He's not crony Blair: Old pals' act; Mandy defends his new Euro job. |location=Glasgow |publisher=Sunday Mail (The Free Library) |date=2004-07-24 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
Raising the spectre of "Tony's Cronies" became a standard method of attacking Blair.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3055153.stm |title='Cronies' charges prompt veto demand |publisher=BBC News |date=2003-07-10 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> This could be seen in the [[Cash for Honours]] scandal, when honours were believed to have been awarded to people in exchange for donations to the Labour Party.<ref name=mail>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/columnists/article-351371/Tonys-cronies-peerages-sale.html |title=Tony's cronies and peerages up for sale |work=Daily Mail |date=2005-06-07 |accessdate=2013-05-03 |first=Stephen |last=Glover}}</ref> It was later discovered that Blair had given an honour to two-thirds of people who had donated over £50,000 to the Labour Party; donors who had given over £1,000,000 were either awarded with a life peerage or a knighthood.<ref name=mail />
In 2007, Blair resigned and [[Gordon Brown]] took over the position of Prime Minister. Brown started to remove most of those who were seen as "Tony's Cronies" from the [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet]], ending accusations of [[cronyism]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-464812/Sweeping-Tonys-cronies.html |title=Sweeping out Tony's cronies |work=Daily Mail |date=2007-06-28 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> However, there were reports of Labour MPs trying to gain favour with Brown after he appointed his former press secretary, [[Ian Austin (politician)|Ian Austin]], as his [[Parliamentary Private Secretary]].<ref name=times>{{cite web|first=Mary Ann |last=Sieghart |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/columnists/article2612656.ece |title=Exit Tony’s cronies, but enter the Brown-nosers |work=The Times |date=2007-02-02 |accessdate=2013-05-03}} {{Subscription required|date=May 2013}}</ref>
== Legacy == After Blair left office, people whom he had appointed to positions of power were still referred to as "Tony's Cronies" in the media.<ref>{{cite news|author=Geoffrey Levy |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2002302/How-onetime-Labour-bigwigs-raking-private-sector.html |title=How onetime Labour bigwigs are raking it in the private sector |work=Daily Mail |date=2011-06-10 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> People who had been given positions by Brown after he had become Prime Minister were referred to as "Brown-nosers".<ref name=times /> In 2010, when the Conservatives formed a new government in coalition with the Liberal Democrats after the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]], the new Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] faced similar accusations to Blair when he was perceived as rewarding with life peerages those who had assisted him. These people were referred to as "Dave's Faves", an intended allusion to "Tony's Cronies".<ref>{{cite news|last=Grice |first=Andrew |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tonys-cronies-to-daves-faves-cameron-repays-some-old-debts-2137104.html |title=Tony's cronies to Dave's faves: Cameron repays some old debts |work=The Independent |date=2010-11-18 |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{Tony Blair |state=autocollapse}} {{New Labour}} {{UK Labour Party}}
[[Category:Tony Blair]] [[Category:Political terms in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:House of Lords]] [[Category:Political catchphrases]] [[Category:New Labour]]

[[Image:JO199411392.png|thumb|The Law as published in the ''[[Journal Officiel de la République Française]]'']]
The '''Toubon Law''' (full name: ''law 94-665 of 4 August 1994 relating to usage of the [[French language]]'') is a law of the French government mandating the use of the [[French language]] in official government publications, in all advertisements, in all workplaces, in commercial contracts, in some other commercial communication contexts, in all government-financed schools, and some other contexts.<ref>See the text of the Toubon Law in English at [http://www.dglf.culture.gouv.fr/droit/loi-gb.htm La Délégation Générale à la Langue Française].</ref>
The law does not concern private, non-commercial communications, such as non-commercial web publications by private bodies. It does not concern books, films, public speeches, and other forms of communications not constituting [[Commerce|commercial activity]]. However, the law mandates the use of the French language in all broadcast audiovisual programs, with exceptions for musical works and "original version" films.<ref name="OpenSociety">See [http://www.eumap.org/topics/media/television_europe/national/france/media_fra1.pdf Television Regulation in France] a 2005 report sponsored by the [[Open Society Institute]].</ref> Broadcast musical works are subject to [[Quota share|quota]] rules under a related law whereby a minimum percentage of the songs on radio and television must be in the French language.<ref name=OpenSociety />
The law takes its common name from [[Jacques Toubon]], who was [[Minister of Culture (France)|Minister of Culture]] when it was passed, and who proposed the law to the [[National Assembly of France]]. A nickname is ''Loi Allgood'' – "Allgood" is a [[morpheme]]-for-morpheme translation of "Toubon" into [[English language|English]] ("All Good" being a translation of "Tout bon") – as the law can largely be considered to have been enacted in reaction to the increasing usage of English in advertisements and other areas in France. As the law sought to strengthen French as the dominant language within the countries and her territories, the law also ‘came under considerable attack from the European Commission which regarded its provisions as particularly offensive to the concept of free competition across national borders.’<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/44961967|title=Identity, insecurity and image : France and language|last=E.|first=Ager, D.|date=1999|publisher=Multilingual Matters|year=|isbn=1853594431|location=Clevedon, England|pages=44|oclc=44961967}}</ref>
==Provisions of the law== One broad provision of the law applying to workplaces is that "any document that contains obligations for the employee or provisions whose knowledge is necessary for the performance of one's work must be written in French." Among other things, this means that computer software developed outside France must have its user interface and instruction manuals translated into French to be legally used by companies in France. The law includes an exception that "these provisions do not apply to documents coming from abroad", but this exception has been interpreted narrowly by the appellate courts. For example, in 2006 a French subsidiary of a US company was given a hefty [[Fine (penalty)|fine]] for delivering certain highly technical documents and software interfaces to its employees in the English language only, and this was upheld by the appellate court.<ref name="GEMedicalSystemsCase">{{cite web |url=http://www.abanet.org/labor/newsletter/intl/2006/Apr/france3.html |title=American Bar Association Report on GE Medical Systems case: French court fines US company for not using French language in France|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806073213/http://www.abanet.org/labor/newsletter/intl/2006/Apr/france3.html|archivedate=6 August 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichJuriJudi.do?oldAction=rechJuriJudi&idTexte=JURITEXT000006948282 Ruling] from the Versailles Court of Appeal, 2 March 2006</ref>
Another broad provision of the law is that it makes it mandatory for commercial advertisements and public announcements to be given in French. This does not rule out advertisements made in a foreign language: it is sufficient to provide a translation in a footnote. This was justified as a measure for the protection of the consumer. Additionally, product packaging must be in French, though, again, translation in multiple languages can be provided.
A similar restriction—though implemented by [[primary legislation]] regulations and not as application of the Loi Toubon—applies to product labeling: product labels should be intelligible and in French, though additional languages may be present.<ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichCodeArticle.do?cidTexte=LEGITEXT000006069565&idArticle=LEGIARTI000006292770 Code de la consommation R112-8]</ref> Some linguistic restrictions on product labeling were found to be incompatible with [[Law of the European Union|European law]],<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61998J0366:EN:NOT Ruling C-366-98 of 12 September 2000], [[Court of Justice of the European Communities]]</ref> particularly the directives concerning the freedom of movement of goods within the [[European Union]]. The French government then issued interpretation notes and amended regulations in order to comply.<ref>Marc Frangi, ''[http://www.cairn.info/revue-internationale-de-droit-economique-2003-1-page-135.htm Le consommateur français entre loi Toubon et droit communautaire]'', Revue internationale de droit économique, De Boeck Université, t. XVII, 1 2003/1, pp. 135-144, {{ISBN|2-8041-4232-9}}, {{DOI|10.3917/ride.171.0135}}</ref>
In another provision, the law specifies obligations for public [[Legal personality#Juridicial persons|legal persons]] (government administrations, et al.), mandating the use of French in publications, or at least in summaries of publications. In France, it is a constitutional requirement that the public should be informed of the action of the government. Since the official language of France is French, it follows that the French public should be able to get official information in French.
Under the Toubon law, schools that do not use French as the medium of instruction are ineligible for government funding. This excludes the [[Breton language]] schools of [[Brittany]].<ref>See [[Breton language]] for a summary of the Toubon Law's impact on the Breton language.</ref><ref>[http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichJuriAdmin.do?oldAction=rechJuriAdmin&idTexte=CETATEXT000008131414 Ruling 238653 of 29 November 2002] from the [[Council of State (France)|Council of State]]: 50/50 French/Breton education cannot be publicly funded.</ref>
Other restrictions concern the use of French in [[academic conference]]s. These are largely ignored by many public institutions, especially in the "hard" scientific fields.<ref>[http://www.senat.fr/questions/base/1990/qSEQ901012253.html Question] from senator Danielle Bidard-Reydet and answer by the Minister of Research [[Hubert Curien]], 1991: the conclusion of a commission of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] is that enforcing the use of French in scientific conferences, through the use of simultaneous translations, would be not only costly but useless, and would damage the reputation of France among the international scientific community. The Ministry thus does not envision coercive measures, which would have the result of reducing the number of internal scientific conferences in France. Thus, the use of simultaneous translation is ''recommended'' (not impose).</ref><ref>[http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/dglf/rapport/2008/Rapport_Parlement08.pdf 2008 Report from the General delegation to French language] to [[Parliament of France|Parliament]], pp. 33-39. The [[French National Centre for Scientific Research|National Centre for Scientific Research]] indicates that strict observance of the law would pose considerable problems. Page 39: 78% of research laboratories have organized or co-organized seminars, in France during the 2006-2007 school year. Out of that number, 62% organized sittings that took place essentially in a foreign language: 47% in humanities and social sciences, 71% in exact sciences. The operators indicated that sometimes sittings took place in a foreign language even though all participants were francophone. This situation took place within 35% of relevant laboratories (thus 16% of all laboratories), in approximately the same proportion in exact sciences and humanities and social sciences.</ref> The original restrictions on colloquia also applied to private bodies, but that was found unconstitutional prior to enactment,<ref>[[Constitutional Council of France|Constitutional Council]], [http://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/conseil-constitutionnel/francais/les-decisions/depuis-1958/decisions-par-date/1994/94-345-dc/decision-n-94-345-dc-du-29-juillet-1994.10568.html 94-345 DC]</ref> on grounds that they violated [[freedom of speech]], and the final form of the law was modified accordingly.
===Enforcement against French subsidiaries of US-based organizations===
In the mid-1990s, soon after the Toubon Law came into force, two French lobbying groups—the ''Association pour la Défense de la Langue Française'' and the ''L'Avenir de la Langue Française''—filed a complaint against [[Georgia Tech Lorraine]], the [[Metz]] campus of the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]]. At the time of the complaint, all classes at this Lorraine school were conducted in English, and all course descriptions on its French Internet web site were in English only. The complaint invoked the Toubon Law to demand that the school's web site must be in French because the web site was effectively a commercial [[advertisement]] for the school's courses.<ref>{{cite news|first=Bruno|last=Giussani|url=http://partners.nytimes.com/library/cyber/euro/1231euro.html|title=Georgia Tech Is Sued For Non-French Web Site|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1996-12-31|accessdate=2008-02-24}}</ref> Although the case was dismissed by the court on a minor legal technicality,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://legalminds.lp.findlaw.com/list/cyberia-l/msg01052.html|title=Victory in France|publisher=[[Findlaw]]|date=1997-06-09|accessdate=2012-01-26}}</ref> and the lobbying groups chose to drop the matter, the school was moved to offer its French website in the French language in addition to English, although classes continued to be in English only.<ref>See [http://www.georgiatech-metz.fr/ Georgia Tech Lorraine website today].</ref>
In 2006, the French subsidiary of the US company [[General Electric|General Electric Medical Systems]] was fined €500,000 plus an ongoing fine of €20,000 per day for not complying with the Toubon law.<ref name="GEMedicalSystemsCase" />
==See also== * [[Language policy in France]] * [[Ordinance of Villers-Cotterêts]] * [[Académie française]] * [[Charter of the French Language|Charter of the French Language, Quebec]]

==External links== * {{fr icon}} [http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/WAspad/UnTexteDeJorf?numjo=MCCX9400007L Text of the Toubon law] * {{fr icon}} [http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/dglf/ Reports] of the general delegation for the French language, from the French Ministry of Culture

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Vermont Energy Investment Corporation | logo = Vermont Energy Investment Corporation Logo 2013.jpg | type = [[Non-Profit]] | foundation = 1986 ([[Chittenden County, Vermont]]) | founder = Beth Sachs
Blair Hamilton | location = [[Image:Flag of Vermont.svg|40px]] [[Chittenden County, Vermont]] | num_employees = approximately 150 area_served = Chittenden County | key_people = Beth Sachs, Scott Johnstone industry = [[Efficient energy use]] | products = | homepage = http://www.veic.org/index.cfm }} '''Vermont Energy Investment Corporation''' or '''VEIC''' is a [[non-profit]] [[organization]] in [[Chittenden County, Vermont]] that seeks to reduce the economic and environmental costs of [[energy]] consumption through [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] and [[renewable energy]] adoption. Since its founding in 1986, the organization has been involved in designing energy efficiency and renewable energy programs in [[North America]] and worldwide. VEIC also operates three large-scale energy efficiency programs in the United States, including [[Efficiency Vermont]], the nation’s first statewide energy efficiency [[utility]].{{cite web|title=Vermont Legislature Resolution|url=http://www.leg.state.vt.us/docs/2012/Acts/ActR490.pdf|page=1}} ==History== VEIC was founded in 1986 by Beth Sachs and Blair Hamilton with a goal to reduce energy costs for consumers by promoting energy efficiency and encouraging the conservation of natural resources.{{cite web|title=Vermont Legislature Resolution|url=http://www.leg.state.vt.us/docs/2012/Acts/ActR490.pdf|page=1}} In particular, they focused their early efforts on helping reduce the burden of energy costs for low income consumers. By 1997, VEIC had implemented energy efficiency measures in nearly 100 low-income multifamily buildings throughout the state of Vermont; it also led a successful effort to establish an ordinance requiring landlords in the city of Burlington to meet a minimum efficiency standard before their buildings could be sold to new owners. Through a partnership with the Vermont Housing Finance Agency, VEIC also helped to establish financing programs and a home energy rating system to help low-income and first-time homebuyers avoid being burdened with high energy costs.{{cite web|title=Climate Change Solutions – Vermont Trims Energy Bills for Low-Income Families|url=http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyNET.exe/40000PQ2.txt?ZyActionD=ZyDocument&Client=EPA&Index=1995%20Thru%201999&Docs=&Query=&Time=&EndTime=&SearchMethod=1&TocRestrict=n&Toc=&TocEntry=&QField=&QFieldYear=&QFieldMonth=&QFieldDay=&UseQField=&IntQFieldOp=0&ExtQFieldOp=0&XmlQuery=&File=D%3A%5CZYFILES%5CINDEX%20DATA%5C95THRU99%5CTXT%5C00000013%5C40000PQ2.txt&User=ANONYMOUS&Password=anonymous&SortMethod=h%7C-&MaximumDocuments=1&FuzzyDegree=0&ImageQuality=r75g8/r75g8/x150y150g16/i425&Display=p%7Cf&DefSeekPage=x&SearchBack=ZyActionL&Back=ZyActionS&BackDesc=Results%20page&MaximumPages=1&ZyEntry=1|publisher=EPA}} In 2000, VEIC won a competitive contract to operate Efficiency Vermont, the first statewide energy efficiency utility in the nation. Efficiency Vermont has been credited as an effective program: * By the end of 2005, annual energy usage in Vermont had been reduced by 98,000 megawatt-hours{{cite news|last=Kardashian|first=Kirk|title=Energy Stars|url=http://www.7dvt.com/2008energy-stars|newspaper=Seven Days|date=30 July 2008}} * In 2007 Vermont became the first state in the nation to turn electrical load growth negative{{cite web|last=Johnstone|first=Scott|title=Energy Efficiency as a Resource: Moving from Inclusion to Front of the Line|url=http://aceee.org/files/pdf/conferences/eer/2011/ML_Johnstone.pdf|publisher=American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy}} * Between 2009-2011, estimated energy savings produced by Efficiency Vermont were 304,000 megawatt-hours{{cite web|title=Efficiency Vermont 2011 Annual Savings Claim|url=http://efficiencyvermont.com/docs/about_efficiency_vermont/annual_reports/2011_Savings_Claim_Summary_EfficiencyVermont.pdf}} * In 2011, efficiency accounted for a 1.91 percent reduction in Vermont’s electricity supply requirements and 790,000 tons of avoided CO2 emissions{{cite web|title=Efficiency Vermont 2011 Annual Savings Claim|url=http://efficiencyvermont.com/docs/about_efficiency_vermont/annual_reports/2011_Savings_Claim_Summary_EfficiencyVermont.pdf}} In 2007, VEIC established a 20-year goal to offset twice the amount of greenhouse gas emissions projected to be emitted in Vermont in the year 2027.{{cite web|title=Vermont Legislature Resolution|url=http://www.leg.state.vt.us/docs/2012/Acts/ActR490.pdf|page=1}} Over the course of 2010-2011, VEIC won competitive contracts to start up and begin operation of additional large-scale energy efficiency programs based in Ohio and Washington, D.C.{{cite news|last=D’Ambrosio|first=Dan|title=Efficiency Vermont serves as a model of energy savings|url=http://www.vermontfuel.com/VFDA_News_files/Efficiency%20Vermont%20Expands.pdf|newspaper=Burlington Free Press|date=22 November 2010}} Efficiency Smart, based in Columbus, Ohio, is a program of energy efficiency services offered to a network of public power companies that are members of American Municipal Power, Incorporated (AMP).{{cite web|title=Efficiency Smart: About US|url=http://efficiencysmart.org/About_Us.aspx}} VEIC operates Efficiency Smart under contract to AMP and has designed the program to save 70,000 megawatt-hours of electricity over the course of its first three years in operation.{{cite news|title=Efficiency Company to Help Utilities in 6 States|url=http://www.vpr.net/news_detail/88280/efficiency-company-to-help-utilities-in-6-states/|newspaper=Vermont Public Radio|date=16 June 2010}} The District of Columbia Sustainable Energy Utility (DC SEU) is operated under contract to the District Department of the Environment in Washington, D.C. The DC SEU contract is held by the Sustainable Energy Partnership, with VEIC serving as the partnership lead.{{cite web|title=District of Columbia Sustainable Energy Utility: About US|url=http://dcseu.com/DCSEU_about_us.aspx}} In February 2012, VEIC, The Clark Group, and Vermont Law School were awarded a $34 million blanket purchase agreement to help the Environmental Protection Agency improve energy efficiency for commercial, institutional, and industrial customers throughout the U.S.{{cite web|last=Sands|first=Laura|title=Clark Group Press Release on EPA Contract|url=http://clarkgroupllc.com/news/Clark_Group_National_Press_Release.pdf}} At a 2012 U.S. Senate forum on jobs, Scott Johnstone, the Executive Director of VEIC, reported that the organization continues to grow, despite the economic recession that began in 2008. According to his statement, from 2005-2012 VEIC increased its number of employees by 130%, and its revenues grew by 286%.{{cite web|title=United States Senate: Steering Committee Meeting on Jobs|url=http://www.sanders.senate.gov/newsroom/photos/gallery/?id=5d38e903-e433-414e-9ad9-ca03bcab2753}} VEIC is also an active resource on transportation efficiency. It is facilitating the state of Vermont’s participation in the Rocky Mountain Institute’s “Project Get Ready” program, which is working to prepare for the electrification of the transportation system. It is also conducting research on least-cost transportation strategies, and best practices for applying energy efficiency principles to travel behavior and consumer purchase decisions in the transportation sector.{{cite news|last=Glitman|first=Karen|title=Creative Corner: A vision for Vermont's transportation future|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/article/20120419/BUSINESS08/120418024/Creative-Corner-vision-Vermont-s-transportation-future?odyssey=mod%7Cnewswell%7Ctext%7CFRONTPAGE%7Cs&gcheck=1&nclick_check=1|newspaper=Burlington Free Press|date=12 April 2012}} ==Publications== *“VEIC and the Energy Efficiency Imperative” (2009) by Blair Hamilton[http://www.veic.org/Libraries/Resource_Library_Documents/VEIC_Overview_-_Energy_Efficiency_Imperative.sflb.ashx] *“The Imperative: Wider and Deeper” (2007) by Blair Hamilton[http://www.veic.org/Libraries/Resource_Library_Documents/VEIC_Overview_-_Energy_Efficiency_Imperative.sflb.ashx] *“What Does it Take to Turn Load Growth Negative?]” (2008) by Scudder Parker, Michael Wickenden, and Blair Hamiltonzz[http://www.veic.org/Libraries/Resource_Library_Documents/VEIC_Overview_-_Energy_Efficiency_Imperative.sflb.ashx] *“Fast Capacity Reduction through Geographically Targeted, Aggressive Efficiency Investment – Early Results from a Vermont Experiment” by Jim Massie, Nancy Wasserman, and Blair Hamilton{{Cite paper|url=http://aceee.org/files/proceedings/2008/data/papers/5_353.pdf|title=Fast Capacity Reduction through Geographically Targeted, Aggressive Efficiency Investment: Early Results from a Vermont Experiment|last=Massie|first=Jim|journal=2008 ACEEE Summer Study on Energy Efficiency in Buildings|year=2008|volume=|pages=|via=ACEEE|first2=Nancy|last2=Wasserman|first3=Blair|last3=Hamilton}} *“Those are Incentives, Not Rebates: Using DSM Funds to Leverage Investments in Low-Income Multifamily Housing” by Elizabeth Chant, Michael Sherman, and Jennifer Chiodo[http://www.veic.org/Libraries/Resource_Library_Documents/VEIC_Overview_-_Energy_Efficiency_Imperative.sflb.ashx] *“Playing with the Big Boys: Energy Efficiency as a Resource in the ISO New England Forward Capacity Market” (2008) by Cheryl Jenkins, Blair Hamilton, and Chris Neme[http://www.veic.org/Libraries/Resource_Library_Documents/VEIC_Overview_-_Energy_Efficiency_Imperative.sflb.ashx] ==See also== *[[Energy Efficiency Implementation]] *[[Efficient energy use]] *[[American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy]] *[[Electric Vehicle]] *[[Energy Star]] *[[Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle]] *[[Rocky Mountain Institute]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.veic.org/ Vermont Energy Investment Corporation] *[http://www.efficiencyvermont.com/ Efficiency Vermont] *[http://www.dcseu.com/ District of Columbia Sustainable Energy Utility] *[http://www.dcseu.com/ Efficiency Smart] {{DEFAULTSORT:Vermont Energy Investment Corporation}} [[Category:Companies based in Vermont]] [[Category:Social programs]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Vermont]] [[Category:Burlington, Vermont]]
